number of helpful: 25 of 30 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Did you love Final Fantasy tactics?Do you love that feeling of accomplishment despite the hellish pain of constant death that rivals even Dark Souls? Do you love deep tactical rewarding strategy based combat?Then Wakfu will probably be the game for you. On its cute and pristine exterior, there's a huge amount of depth and punishing dungeons and temples. This isn't your average MMO, you wipe in a temple that can take nearly an hour to complete? Well that's too bad, you'll have to start from the very beginning. This isn't some game you can get away with spamming. Positioning, timing and execution is key. Even basic battles against mobs have a strategic depth to them that feels foreign to an MMORPG. This game runs on turn based grid combat, you level your character like any other in an RPG, however each element has its specialties. Fire is typically AOE (area of effect) , Earth is typically direct damage, Water is usually healing or mobility debuffs or buffs with some damage mixed in. Air is usually knockbacks or line telegraph attacks. But that's only typically, each class feels extremely different. From manipulating time, to picking up your foes and tossing them, to entirely relying on lady luck in combat. Wakfu brings a whole new fresh style to combat that I've never experienced in an MMO before.Words of warning, if you like questing, you'll find it extremely lacking on quests until you reach the out-lying islands of the nations of the World of Twelve. However they continue to work on updating the game with more quest lines that guide you into areas. I say your first real challenging quest chain is on the Wild Estates, where a mixture of puzzle solving, challenging battles, even sports and an Indiana Jones style hunt for an artifact will take center stage. Did I mention its really hard? Because, it's really bworking hard! There's a large slew of crafting professions, an entirely player run economy, and the most challenging PVE MMO experience I've ever had. As for the PVP I haven't experienced too much of it. It depends on the server you join but the economy has been somewhat at a standstill and it's more likely you will get trades from your haven bag or face to face than the market. Kamas, the games currency aren't all that hard to get however, especially considering you can mint them yourself.Wakfu is a beautifully designed, deep and well made game that is literally the most challenging experience I've had in an MMO, rivals even what I experienced in my days of EVE in terms depth of combat. There's really a whole slew of possibilities you can approach a battle based on your class and playstyle, those possibilities yet nail biting, hair pulling difficulty is something I do have to admit that I love. We need more games like Wakfu, not MMOs, just games period. This game is the XCOM: Enemy Unknown of MMOs, it's about as tense too. Give the game a shot, add me on Steam if you'd want to party up, don't be afraid to ask questions to the community either, they're quite understanding and helpful, there will be a few bad eggs I'm sure.  In closing, Wakfu is a generously made game, with a lot of love and hardwork put into it, down to the extremely artistic style handcrafted areas, and lovable design

number of helpful: 23 of 27 people (85%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												In one word: obsolete.As you can tell from my hours played, I used to play this game. A lot. And this is only the hours logged on this character on steam, I had probably double this overall. However, I haven't touched this game in over a year. It runs on an obsolete version of java and the creators show no real intentions on updating it anytime soon. When I first started, it was a very vibrant game, full of excitement and fun. However, like so many others have commented, it's not what it used to be. The fighting system has been revamped over and over, so much so that it's just not fun to learn a new system every three months. It's not fun to deal with terrible support and a system that barely scrapes by. It's a shame, because this game used to be amazing. The music for this game is incredible, to this day I still go back and look up my favorite songs and listen to them on youtube. Like everyone else has said, the creators have pushed themselves into a corner by alienating the fanbase by removing exciting features, putting crap into the game, and punishing players for the actions of the few. I wish I could recommend this game, I really do. There was a time when I could; that time is gone. This game is on the downhill slope, which is sad considering where it has fallen from. That being said, if you want to give it a try, go for it. It's free and you can always use this as a time sink. But this game had its glory days, and those days are passed.

												[English at the end] Wakfu  o MMORPG mais F2P do mercado.Comeo com essa frase para voc ter certeza de que ele  grtis de verdade, no h limitadores sobre o que fazer, e justamente por isso fao questo de apoi-lo comprando itens que gosto no ogrines shop. Wakfu tem fortes aspectos de sandbox.Se voc jogou Ragnarok Online, ento j est treinado para Wakfu. Imagine um RO evoludo: com controle do ambiente feito pelos jogadores; itens super diversos feitos por jogadores; poltica feita por jogadores; risco de deixar seu personagem ruim se no pensar direito na build, guerras e tratados de paz, etc. Mas tambm temos o grind, que se voc no diversificar fazendo outras atividades (que no so poucas) te deixar entediado.  Wakfu  muito bem desenhado. um jogo bonito, no se pode negar. Seus equipamentos so realmente usados por personagens carismticos, que comeam usando coisas "fofas", que transparecem bastante o "newbie", para um dia ficarem imponentes e ameaadores. Os locais visitados possuem caractersticas fortes, que deixam claro, por exemplo, a nao daquele territrio, e visitar os mapas  sempre agradvel. Wakfu  estratgico.H muitos elementos estratgicos em Wakfu, do combate (que  feito por turnos) at como voc lida com o ambiente com seu personagem. H estratgia no craft, na poltica (que oferece diversos cargos para os jogadores), no estilo de jogo dos personagens e na interao entre eles, nos itens que voc usar, nas habilidades, enfim, falar em Wakfu  falar em estratgia.Ento se voc chegou at aqui, d uma chance ao jogo. Uma vez nele, leia, entenda-o, sinta-se livre de verdade, sem um caminho pr-definido a seguir. No se prenda s misses, faa-as quando quiser, se quiser. Use a janela de archievements para guiar seus objetivos e viva o mundo de Wakfu  sua maneira.E faa o tutorial!______ Wakfu is the most F2P MMORPG in the market. Beginning with this phrase for you to make sure that he is really free, no limiters on what to do, and rightfully so I must support him by buying items I like in Ogrine shop.  Wakfu has sandbox in his veins. If you played Ragnarok Online, then you're already trained to Wakfu. Imagine a RO evolved: the control of environment made by the players; various items made by players; policy made by players; risk of build your character wrong, wars and peace treaties, etc. But we also have the grind, if you do not diversify doing other activities (which are many) that leave you bored.  Wakfu is very well designed. It's a beautiful game, one can not deny. The equipment is actually used by charismatic characters, who start using "cute" things, which are reflected quite the "newbie" for a day become imposing and threatening. The locals visited have strong characteristics which make it clear, for example, the nation that territory, and visit the maps is always nice.  Wakfu is strategic. There are many strategic elements in Wakfu, the fight (which is done in turns) to how you handle the environment with your character. There are craft strategy, politics (which offers various positions for the players), the game style of the characters and the interaction between them, the items you will use, skills, finally, speaking Wakfu is speaking strategy. So if you got this far, give the game a try. Once there, read, understand it, feel free indeed, without a pre-defined path to follow. Do not hold on to the quests, do them when you want, if you want. Use the window archievements to guide your goals and live the world of Wakfu your way. And do the tutorial!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												It's kinda rare to see Turn Based Strategy MMORPG.Wakfu is one of those rare gem. The gameplay kinda similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, but you only control 1 character, well. with sidekicks though, but still not much.Now on to the review.+ So many different class to choose of.  Each class have quite a lot of skill, you could make your own unique build.+ There's a profession system in this game, so apart from the main game itself, you could become a farmer, a blacksmith, tailor, and many more.+ Community oriented game, you can't sell your stuff to NPC, this game is really community based game, you must actually sell it to people, or... just throw it out. There's Region president election, Guild, and many more. You can join the bad guys, or become a guard instead.+ For people who prefers playing alone, there's a sidekick system. At least, there's someone to accompany you. Though, i recommend you playing with actual players.- The community is almost non-existent, many people said this game is still alive, but that's not applied in my case.  I'm playing in asia server, not sure about other server though.- Grindfest, and it's even worse than other MMO in general in my opinion.- Customization, There's costume and stuff, but... well, it's not rare to see people with a same face.- Progression, this game had quite an interesting story, but to progress in the main story is really hard. The level gap to actually progress in this game is really high. If you have a friend to play with you, i really recommend this game, It's really fun to play wakfu together. If not, find oneright away, join a guild, and have fun.

												This game is great... I mean it.  One of the best and most unique games you will ever find.I've been playing this game for years now (before it comes to steam) and I was in love with it.  I had many charecters at cap level... But one day.. my account got hacked ( I mean all gamers know this would happen to them once or twice in their gaming life it's not a big deal right??) SO I did what anyone else would do and opened a ticked... but guess what they will do for you? NOTHING! ya they might reset you password if you want, but other than that NO... NOTHING.so imagine playing for few years in this game and some hacker come in steal all your cash, spend all your cash-shop currency to buy stuff and give it to his main, sell all your rare armors and weapons.... so I basicly ended with 8 max level charecters naked with no cash... just nothing.  And they will not do nothing for you.  If you don't believe just go to their website and check it for your self.Link to their "account theft information" : https://support.ankama.com/hc/en-us/articles/201609246-My-account-was-stolen-what-do-I-do-and you will find this warning at the begininga "Warning: although Support is able to help you regain access to your account, they can do nothing about any losses and modifications resulting from the theft. All stolen items or kamas are permanently lost."So ya... Go ahead and play this awesome game... invest all your time (AND MONEY) in it... but if your account got hacked one day... you can kiss it goodbye.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I would recommend this game, but there are certain things about it that different kinds of gamers may or may not like, I'll try to sum up some of the specific qualities.1: Like most MMOs it's a long grind to the higher levels, but it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing over and over, generally you get to go through different dungeons and fight new monsters the more you level so you aren't always doing the same thing.2: You have specific skills you can build, everything from Farming/baking to being a jeweler there's lots of stuff you can do other than punching monsters faces all day, you don't absolutely have to if you're the kind of person who just likes fighting, but it can be helpful and even fun to learn these skills, some sidequests involve using these skills as well.3: There is a story to the game but it's really not the main focus until you level up drastically, but even so there are plenty of other things to occupy your time in this game, really half of it feels like you're making your own story with other players, which moves me on to the next topic.4: Politics, yes I said politics, there is a political and economic system in the game world that is run by the players, you can vote for elections or even become governer yourself, laws are set to keep the economy well (or to leech off of other players if they're a dirty politician) not to mention if you break the law you will be labled at a ciminal that other players will attack, and if you are caught then you will have your character sent to jail, also laws are in place to keep the ecosystem in order, which once again moves me onto the next topic.5: Ecosystem, yes there's indeed an ecosystem in this game, you want wood? Plant some trees but don't cut too many down, want to hunt some monsters? Make sure too many of them don't get killed but also don't let there be too many ect ect. There are generally laws in place to help keep it balanced.6: Character Classes, there are a total of fourteen different classes to choose from "Damage dealers tanks and healers oh my!" There's tons of variety in terms of how each class plays, each have their own mechanics making none of them truly "useless" Yes there's one that's overpowered but even that one has a down side, so in terms of classes you won't be dissapointed.So if the things I just mentioned sound interesting and maybe even fun I would highly reccomend trying this one out, it has a beautiful art style and TONS of content to keep you playing!

												EDITI played this quite a bit since I wrote the review and even got some friends to try it. Thing is, I don't like MMOS. There is something about it that just doesn't work for me.That being said, this game is an amazing turn based strategy game. If you like MMOs and turn-based combat, do try it!If you're like me, it's not unlike any MMO. It gets boring too fast.Original review-----------------------------------------------------------------------This game has one of the best turn based combat I've ever played. All playable classes have 20 spells and 5 passives you can skill and level up, allowing you to build it any way you want to suit your tastes. There is a lot of ennemies and they all feel unique.But that's pretty much it. There is no drive to level up, very few quests beside some for the intro, some milestones and the dailies. That's enough for me but it makes it hard to get friends into the game.Also, the politics, crafting and environnement things seem like useless or almost useless gimmicks to me.On top of that, the game have a lot of issues. The Steam achievements are not working (and at this point, I doubt they ever will). When my friend created an account, he got locked into a different region than mine and he gave up on the game.Give me a propper coop RPG with those classes and ennemies and I would buy it any time.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Wakfu is a phenominal game filled with an innovative turn based battle system. Very similar to final fantasy tactics and other games of the genre. The tutorial is long and tedious because it has to be. The battle system is complex to those new to the genre, but once you can look past that; it's a game that you can tell lots of love and creativity was poured into it. Classes~ They're so many classes to choose. They vary from the typical archer and warrior to flying faeries and time robots.  Each class has it's own individual spells and abilities. For example, I have an Eniripsa. The Eniripsa is a support/healer class that can spec into fire, air, or water abilities. Without getting too much into this to prevent spoilers, (and because of my ignorance considering I have only played around 20+ hours) I can assure you that each class is innovative and will be fun to play.People~ People fuel everything in this game. They're no npcs, not too many quests, yet why is this game so fun? Because people make the combat system REALLY ING FUN. You find a party of about 5+ people to do this exceptionally hard dungeon or invade another person's territory ( at level 18 you pick a civilization to live in) and after 25 hours I'm still having so much fun. Professions- If you want to plant a seed. Plant it ing anywhere. If you want to mine a rock go build a bomb and blow up the rocks to find the rare minerals within. If you wanna go trample on someone else's freshly planted seeds ( you btw) then go do that. There's total free roam in this game. ZERO RESTRANTS. Art style/music~  Wakfu is very colorful. Has pretty good mustic, and a flowing animation. Don't be fooled by it's cartooney style though; this game is ing bloody. If you wanna go kill a cat and cut off it's fur go ahead. The blood will be on the picture in your inventory. The games completely free~ That's right, it's free. Go play it you nerd.

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												After having played for a good month or so, I have to say, this is a rare find among rpgs. Albeit starting the game is mildly difficult, it's a fun and interesting game to play! For what it's worth, I love this game mostly because it's all about the player.The economy is not run based on a setup from the developers, it's completely player-based, meaning you can set up shop in the little customizable bag you are given at the beginning of the main part of the game. Not only that, but there are a bunch of balanced, customizable classes you can jump into depending on your play style! Couple that with spells you have to use to improve, gear you can craft/find/buy from others, and all sorts of bonuses like Clan Member bonuses and Guild bonuses, you can increase your stats and quickly find a build for yourself! If that wasn't enough of a hook for the gameplay, you have several opportunities to "Restat", or change up all your spells and ability bonuses!There are a few major downsides to the game: There are NO NPC characters that are useful. By this, I mean there are no shopkeepers or helpful questline helpers, it's all based on you and your groups. This might be bad for some people, but this means you can literally cut through all the crap with hirelings and stuff, and just find like-minded players to work alongside!+ The game is simple to work with, using mostly the right and left mouse buttons to control your character and your surroundings.+ You control the environment! You can decide what crops to take and what all is removed from the area, like herbs, trees, and even the monsters!+ The economy is easy to understand, you sell anything at whatever price you want! It's up to the player that wants what you have to pay the price.+ The graphics are good, as well as the sprites and animations!- There are bugs, as with every game. If you spot something, report it, please, the devs will want to know what is going wrong.- Guilds are at a downside, as there are what are called Haven Worlds, or a World for your guild members to use. Others can slip in and steal stuff from it if you aren't careful, and you'll want to realize you probably WON'T be getting one for a long time if you're a new or semi-poor guild.- PvP is included, so those of you who are low-lvl with high professions, beware other players! Some will want to steal all your crops and leave you nothing in return!- You have to reintroduce anything missing into the environment. If there are no more Ash Trees, to name something important, then if you have the seedlings for it, you'll be forced to replant.There are ways around all the farming/environment stuff, but until you get enough money to buy the Haven Gems needed, it's a bit much to go after. Alot of the players love to help one another out, so ask questions if you want to know something. That said, enjoy playing Wakfu, and hope to see you in the World of Twelve!P.S. if you steal my crops, I'll shoot you. It's as simple as that. D:<

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												I am not very experienced with Wakfu (as of this review) but I have got to say I was excited to hear that it was coming to Steam, and was free to play. Wakfu is a pretty good sized media franchise from France, there are currently 5 games "in universe", 4 released, they are Dofus, Dofus Arena, Islands of Wakfu, Wakfu, and Krogmaster (a tabletop, digital tie in involving minifigures). There are also multiple animated series and movies, including the animated Dofus and Wakfu series. Overall there is alot of lore to take from, and the universe is rich and fun to look at.Wakfu itself however is a pretty good game in my book, It feels like it has alot of strategy, combat wise, compared to most modern mmo's. The level cap in the game is pretty darn high though, so it may feel a bit grindy at times. But with the large and varied amount of classes and builds, I have got to say you wont run out of things to try!Overall I recommend anyone who is a fan of mmo's or turn based strategy games to take a look at Wakfu, and I recommend everyone take a look at the series as a whole!Edit: The game has been released on Steam for a while now, so I have a few additional notes.1. The player population seems to have increased, and is pretty lively compared to what it was before (at least in my opinion.)2. I just realized that the Steam achievements no longer unlock, I dont know what the deal with that is but it should not cause any real problems, its just a minor nuisance.3. have fun!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												At first, Wakfu is a fun game. It has a really unique gameplay style and fun characters. However, once you get farther into the game, you notice problems that start to pop up. Its starts with small things. Maybe your character bugs out a little, or your spells don't work the way they should, and it isn't too big of a problem to begin with.But then these things stack up. And up and up and up. The development team is horrifically slow when it comes to fixing issues. Well actually, I take that back. Whenever there is a bug that HELPS players, it gets fixed very very quickly. But if you've got a gamebreaking bug that halves the damage you deal? Well, maybe they will get to it in three or four patches. And you get a patch once every two months if you are lucky. Whats that, your class is broken? Don't worry, you can always buy the 30$ class change!And don't even get me started on the support, oh lord. I sent in an issue, and a week later, after not hearing anything from them, I tried to contact them again. Again no response. So I tried to contact them a THIRD time, and finally, after almost a month, they contacted me back and said they had looked at the issue, and decided to do nothing about it.You'll notice I have a lot of hours on this game. That isn't counting the time I put into it BEFORE it was released on steam. Its because they keep promising to fix things. Every patch that comes out I think, hey,  They continue to try and put more and more things into the game without ever fixing the old stuff.  And I hope you like doing hours of research in order to play games! Many stats and spells are ambiguous, and there is NOWHERE in game that explains what they do. So, you have to scour the forums, hoping that your question has been answered somewhere, and that if you do find an answer, it isn't outdated.TL;DR this is "Wasted Potential: The Game". The base concept of the game is great, and so much could have been done with it, but in the end it just leads to bitter disappointment.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I have played Wakfu since the first beta. Since the very start of the game. Since 2011. I thought Ankama Games had the right idea by combining their great game with a great video game company like Valve. Since Ankama Games is a French game company, creating a connection with the United States and other countries really helped the game with one of the problems it had, population of the English servers. The things that make this game great are the ideas introduced into the game mechanics itself.The grid-based strategy aspect of the game, combined with the different ways of stat growth and play made this game trully creative with the way players enjoyed the game on a fighting aspect. Another great form of the game is the creative design of the world of Wakfu. Every city, every character, every monster is unique and beautiful. One more great feature of the game is the way real people manipulate with the enviornment, the government, and the people who play the game. Wakfu shines with the idea that people have everything and anything to do with the world in which the players play in. The player can manipulate the mobs in given areas. The player can vote for government officals to enact rules for the country to follow.However, no game is perfect. Wakfu has problems, and unfortunatly the problems happen to be fairly large.Because Wakfu is a game made from a French company, support is not the best when something happens to happen, whether it be in the game or in real life. Although the content is large and the world of Wakfu is large, content seems to be lacking for people who don't want to 'level up'. There aren't many different ways to enjoy the game to its fullest, and although Ankama Games has tried to include ways of enjoying the game, it doesn't seem enough to really keep the players they recieve.I believe Wakfu is a great game and it should be looked at for players who want something different in their MMO. However, Wakfu lacks the ability to keep the players they recieve and although I greatly enjoy the game, and everything it provides, I can't help hoping for more of the game. 7/10

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
"STEP INTO A LIMITLESS UNIVERSE" - WakfuWhat is Wakfu? Wakfu is a limitless universe, with 15+ classes, cute graphics, an amazing amount of content, 17 professions, nature management, government and politics, turn-based combat, player-driven markets, and most of all, 99% of all content is FREE.Wakfu lets you play as a character in a vast universe, to travel it, to traverse all kinds of terrain, to explore, to meet new friends or enemies, but most of all, to enjoy.You can choose amongst 15+ classes (that's a lot!), each with their own unique skills and way of combat, and you are also able to learn and master 17 different professions, from farming, cooking, baking to even tailoring. You can have all of the professions, but it's up to you on what you want to level.This game has a dynamic environment; this means that the world isn't fixed. It's up to us, the players, to plant if the environment lacks plants and to reap if there is too much. It's up to us to decide what will become of the environment.With that being said, a player can lean towards being beneficial (Wakfu) or destructive (Stasis) towards the environment. Wakfu and Stasis are paths you can choose on how you interact with the environment, planting plants, trees and monsters seeds makes you lean towards Wakfu, while cutting down trees, harvesting plants and others make you lean towards Stasis. Most people misunderstand this as Wakfu being good and Stasis being bad, but the proper statement is that: Wakfu is growth as Stasis is regulation. We can't live in a world with a tree in every grid cell, right?Economy is also purely player-driven, you won't find an NPC buying your items for Kamas (the only currency), you'll have to find other people to buy it from you, or sell it in the outpost, where other players see items for sale, easier and in a more convenient way. There are 4 nations that a player can join upon reaching a certain level, each with their own respective territories, laws and government.Politics also play a role in the universe of Wakfu, every 2 weeks, there comes an election wherein a governor is chosen by the players. It's up to the Governor to change laws, pick members for the government and handle relations with other nations.Conclusion? I don't know if you'll like it as much as other people and I do, but just give it a try, play it and you'll find out.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Great MMO Clicker, I highly recommend this if your looking for a relaxing but still challenging game. Beautiful graphics, very  fun but serious story line, an ok class system, and most of all, friendly player base. It's not hard at all to join a guild, players manage the ecosystem, politics, and economy, and they do it well. It is not a pay to win, but pay to play is available. I never used the p2p but I certainly would if I didn't have bills to pay! Although it is a major improvment from Dofus, there are a few bugs that can interfere and hurt your experience on the game. The game is java based and the game client tends to leak memory causing your game to lag or "stall out" and even disconnect you. Some players can take the game too serious and PWN players that just unlocked pvp or players that forgot to turn off their pvp. The reason I make that point is because the players that PWN are not just PKing but are rude and nasty. One last thing, the story is not complete and continues with updates every 4 or 5 months from what I have seen. I consider it an up and a down; It keeps you coming back, but who likes a cliffhanger.Overall, This is definatley a must play. AND IT HAS STEAM TRADING CARDS!

												Pros:+ Amazing when playing with friends (feels like you're part of a team/party in something like final fantasy)+ Good game design decisions all around+ Some classes offer WAY more difficulty then others+ Classes combine well with eachother in combatPro/Con:+-  You get all of your abilities very early on (You get to do stuff in the early game)+_ You cant sell things to NPCs, everything is done through the "auction house"+_ Can be very grindy (alot less with friends, but still grindy)+_ Alot to learn (for sure if you take the more difficult classes)+_ "fast-travel" is basicly free aslong as the distance isent super longCons:- While everybody gets their own drops in a fight, harvesting materials (like trees or ores) are not instanced, thus making it a race for resources if alot of people are around (thankfully they do grow fast and in the case of trees you can replant them yourself)- Alot less fun solo, you do get a companion that you control yourself, but still way less fun then an acctual playerOverall, this is the first game to make me quit out of time consumption and not out of boredom, highly recommend it, for sure once it acctually hits open beta.Beta keys:  https://secure.wakfu.com/en/steam (not always there, but you can give it a shot every now and then)

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												ANKAMA BANNED ME BECAUSE I TRIED TO SETTLE A PAYMENT DISPUTE! Ok so I heard tons of stories of how terrible the support for this game is, but I didn't want to believe it was a common thing. That it was just a problem with a few unlucky players and maybe there are just a couple bad employees. Boy was I wrong. I went to buy the drheller and the krosmos harness for the week 3 wakfunding campaign and I only received the confirmation email that activates the in purchases in game for the krosmos harness. I sent a ticket to ankama support as well as PayPal, but they BANNED  ME because apparently the drheller was a "fraudulent purchase".  Aside from my personal experience, if you want to talk about the actual game itself, I definitely know now why 80% of the veteran players from years ago abandoned this game like a sinking ship.A lot of complaints I read about are pointless nerfs, next to NO support for North American players, updates are exclusive to end game players and they NEVER fix or expand on the current content for the early game players. If you do try to play the game just to check it out keep in mind that the world supposedly has a LOT less players than it used to from what I've read in the forums, and there's a TON of grinding involved, I didn't mind this because I do enjoy tactical RPGs and I loved the class system, and I started playing about a month ago so I wasn't personally affected by these less than stellar updates.But man, this is completely ridiculous and a freaking shame considering I'm a big fan of the Dofus and Wakfu TV series and comics. I really wanted to see more of this game to make a decision on whether or not it's worth the time, but I guess that's not happening. Season 3 of Wakfu better be worth the money I lost.EDIT I got my response to my ticket, and before they'll look into my case they want to see my birth certificate, passport, or driver's license... I guess this is common practice for most mmos when it concerns your account but I'm still not too keen on giving away crucial identity information to a foreign company. Despite my saltiness I do recommend checking out Treasures of Kerubim and Wakfu, as well as the tie in comics. You can find English translations on brotherhoodoftofuv2 on tumblr.

												Visuals - This game gives rather colorful and diverse artwork. Every place you go in this game will be different from another place. I'd say the developers spent a lot of time making the open world as beautiful as 2D can possibly get.Gameplay - As many people will say, this game plays similar to Final Fantasy tactics. It seems kinda iffy to begin with. You incarnate into Astrub and do some mercenary work. Than a giant tv face guy tells you that you are the chosen one to defeat the mighty Ogrest. I'd have to say the story for me is the weakest aspect of the game.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Again and again I find myself returning to this game, only to encounter a diffirent disbalance and same broken AI. One would think that since the game came out, developers could adress these issues. Instead, we get alternative questlines and new cash shop items.The gameplay is enjoyable. The artstyle is good. But the world feels very, very empty.The game was originally intended to have a community. Players run faction politics, entire economy and even location ecosystems. It has now gotten to a point where people jump to another server, just because it has a spike in population. Many people who return to the game after a long time seem to be bewildered by the state of affairs.There is variety of classes, each with their own, unique abilities that grow stronger as you use them. This is great, except because of the aforementioned imbalance, which in turn leads to a class getting nerfed or revamped. Remember that character that you played a while ago that you really liked? Here, have a totally diffirent one.Crafting is a grindfest. If there was an active economy going, this would have been easier. But if you want to create a good item, you have to personally collect all the components required for a specific item and craft it. Both of these require a good amount of time to get the skills for. And the list of required components can often be quite extensive. This repeated process is the only way to advance in a crafting profession.There's an extensive list of unique enemies, who often come in matched groups, so as long as you advance in level or just travel a lot, you get to face various new challanges. This only lasts until later levels, when the grind sets in, or when you just need to acquire specific components or a piece of armor. This uniqueness also causes AI to frequently do random things. And woe upon you if you picked a summoner class - healers who prefer full health targets over dying allies, melee summons who decide to just step back a bit and skip turn...I wish the game would do better, I really do. But so far I've come to be repeatedly dissapointed.

content:
Posted: March 18
Rating: 6/10What I like about this game is that its a turn base strategy mmo game.Could have been a decent game but there are some reasons why i only gave it a 7/10 ratingbut with the recent update its 6/10.Will I recommend this game to everyone? Read the PRO's and CON's then you decide if you want to play the game.PROS:* 17 Playable classes each with its own unique set of skills.* You can create up to 5 character per server although you have to pay for 3 more character slots.* Customization for gender, eye color, hair color, skin color, hair style and default outfit.* Eco system which lets player control the environment per map* Haven Bag that lets player create and customize his own house/place where in he can do garden, crafting and also sell stuff.* Lots of things to craft and do.* Lots of dungeons you can explore.* You can join a nation and colonized a territory or even vote for ruling governor(for booster users only).* You can create/join a guild and get world haven where in you can create your on place to farm, fish, mine, etc...* Hidden treasures and secrets.CONS:* Achievements on steam does not work.* Bugy, not just few but lots of them* some environment buff dont work properly you will have to relog to fix this problem* when you trade with someone sometimes you wont be able to cancel the trade or close it, again you will need to relog.* sometimes when you are in a battle there is a bug where in you can't attack properly, again relog.- when you have a poor connection sometimes the sprites are missing, broken or mixed where a    fish turns into a box.- and so much more... isnt that fun exploring bugs? ^_^* Some updates and events are not announced on time.* To much grinding and farming.* Player Base is getting low.* PVP is not balanced.* There are things that only a booster pack user can do.Recent Update 1.52PROS:* added a ranking system for dungeons* added new crafting itemsCONS:* They changed the repeatable quest in maps where in now it gives you less exp, you will need to be a booster pack user to get the max exp reward bonus that it use to give. This game is already a grinding game and then you make decisions like that and the best part is that you dont show that in your updates hiding it to players. Way to go anakma you'll defenitely going to lose players with that, keep it up. ^_^

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Visuals----The one thing that's still great about this game. Ankama took their existing universe of Dofus and expanded on it. Everything is nice and lovely and vibrant, the setting is very consistent with itself. It's a great example of worldbuilding making a game notable and able to stand out above the crowds.Gameplay---I can handle most turnbased things, Xcom isn't a stranger to me in any way, but the turn based style does not lend itself well to multiplayer in this fashion. The gameplay doesn't change that much between level 20 and level 100. There's no real defined niche that you can build your character to fill that can't be filled by someone else of your class with 5 minutes of free time. All in all I think they kind of lost sight of what made the game good in the first place and decided that it was easier to update Dofus than it was to flesh out Wakfu more.Tech-----Somehow, a PC that runs Overwatch at 1080p at 100fps constant has terrible jitters in this super simple java game. I'm running 16gb of ram but the game chugs even when I use launch paramters on the standalone client and feed it up to 12gb of ram. Overall, the game is a 3.5/5 for me if you like turn based tactical games. I'd suggest something else if you are looking for an MMO to play with friends however, the community is just about nonexistant(on Nox anyways, the North American server)

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												If I could give a mid-ranged review? I would. The game had and still has a lot of potential and nostalgic feel to it for those of us especially who enjoyed games like Final Fantasy Tactics.The Crafting and Gathering system is huge; big enough to be it's own thing really. You could almost make a Wakfu version of Stardew Valley out of all the stuff you can craft and the things you have to gather, how and where. For my inner crafter and explorer.. it's great! I love teh fact you can transplant not only plants, but animals and mobs into different areas.. though the current system still gets abused, the way they discourage that abuse is a creative addition to faction gameplay I simply didn't expect.. and still appreciate. Multi-level maps are lots of fun to run around on usually, though there are some drawbacks.The downside hits when you get into progression through the rest of game. It's slow, really slow after you get through the opening city quest. And I mean this is crawling a mile on your belly through a corn field not knowing what direction you're even supposed to be going, slow. Getting anywhere with dungeons is a pain alone unless they're severely underlevel, or you manage to find a party (good luck with that!) And actual quests are so few and far between on the slow grind, or worth so little that it actually makes it feel slower at times. Combat is fun but difficult solo at times, and the overall health loss when you die doesn't help encourage solo players towards the story or content at all in my opinion. The maps, while fun to explore especially when they become more multi-level? Can be very confusing for that same reason, as the way up to a higher tier of the map or down to a lower one isn't always clear: wasting a lot of your time running in circles only to find out you can't even get to X place from where you're at or without crossing some bridge a zone over.Don't get me wrong, it's lots of fun if you have one to three people to play with all the time.. but otherwise main progression and catching up if you get behind your group can be really tough. It's incredibly easy to have double the level gathering and crafting, from what you have as a battle class, if that tells you anything. Which, is fine with me at this stage. As I said, that part can be a lot of fun on it's own. Still grindy after a certain level, but fun.Overall, I do reccomend this game if you like crafting and gathering, or especially if you have a friend (or more than one preferrably) to play it with: but definitely take this into consideration. If you're not up for a grind of any kind, or want to play through the main content on your own sometimes? This probably isn't the game for you past Astrub (the first City.) If you do enjoy crafting, gathering and exploring though? Try it. You can get lost in this game for hours if you do.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Updating This Review from formerly Nov 7, 2014Wakfu is a unique game like most have already told you, it mixes MMO with turn-based battling ALA Final Fantasy Tactics and to a lesser extent, things like X-com, though the visuals may seem cartoony the game is still very complex in my opinion and you need awareness and quick-thinking to fight some higher level enemies with specific mechanics and priorities in battle. The sad thing about Wakfu is that it has changed several times in the past years, some for good and some for bad. I still stick with my original belief that this is a fun game with the potential for enjoyment for a lot of people.The Good :Character builds and customization are great, although the last change to the system limited potential, I still am able to make builds that are to my flavor and effective in combat past level 150+ where I currently am.I use the heroes system they have to play my myriad of characters who usually complement each other in some way. The Heroes system was in beta for some time, and essentially just allows you to play three characters on your account for a fee. (Booster + Heroes System costs around the same amount as a standard MMO sub).The Challenge system in this game adds much needed variety to farming, though some challenges are left better suited to particular characters in the game. Being turn based, you're able to effectively "backstab" enemies for more damage on your turn by being behind them. Some challenges require all enemies be killed this way for a bonus to exp and drop rate. Sometimes its worth it, sometimes its not, choose how to spend your time and you may cut your grinding in half.Dungeon System in this game is interesting, and it is good for the most part, being able to set dungeons to an easier difficulty for less rewards or making them extra hard for potentially double the rewards is great for people who need to learn a boss mechanic or feel up to overpowering a boss/groups and getting a better chance at those rare/unique items they seek so desperately.The community in Wakfu has always been an interesting one, somewhere between hospitable to passionate individuals who try their best to work with Ankama and revive this dying game. They love the game, and so do I, and I wish to see it thrive. It shows when I login and people are hanging out, talking about strategies, calling for dungeon runs, selling their stuff, and generally just wanting to have fun together.The Bad :Wakfu is a hard game to get into past a certain point, while being visually welcoming to those of a young age, you will quickly understand the elemental system and either learn to memorized enemies weakness/strength or grow frustrated as your damage is abyssmal because you forgot X monster was strong against X element.The customization for the game as far as battles has become a little more limited since the changes, and you will see optimized builds (like any other game) are almost necessary with the lack of choice. Though you can skimp on one or two skills, always having the core ones assures near maximum potential for damage/survivability especially against enemies who may have strong resistances against two of your three elements which each character has access to spells for.Grinding can be pretty bad unless you have friends to run dungeons with, and the shame is that the heroes system while making it fun for soloers, makes going in with randoms more unnecessary as well. With just yourself and a single other friend paying a premium subscription you can practically do all dungeons in the game, or six box accounts like some have in the past.They somewhat recently changed how gear in the game drops, claiming it was for more "unique builds" with elements being rolled out randomly with gear but this has just made rerolling stones more valuable and frustrating. Now you can't simply get a set and use it, you have to get the elements for your build correct as well. Just a chore, really, along a lot of other systems in the game unless you nibble at the grinding of mats, tokens, and crafting a bite at a time.Ankama mostly puts out cosmetics while delivering small trickles of actual content, changing the game seemingly with no input from the community (Though you see when Flat responds in the forums all the time) and its moreso they can't seem to filter the "bad" suggestions from the "good". Bugs still exist in the game for 3+ years ago. Oddly enough its their birthday for this game as of writing this and I feel like the cake is a little stale.The Overall TL;DR VersionWakfu is a game I love, and this review is probably biased as hell, but I am aware of it. In saying that, would I recommend this game to new people? Yes, for a while, levels 1-50 might be fun to dabble in but once you get 80+-100+ is when the game "starts" and thats when it will either make you or break you. Do I think its worth playing right now? Maybe? Depends on how much you can tolerate. Bugs, graphical issues, optimization problems, class balances, promises both delivered poorly or well, or not at all plague this game. It has its faults. THIS GAME IS NICHE AS **** AND YOU SHOULD KNOW THAT GOING IN! Besides that, I enjoy it, I put away my 13 dollars a month for it, even when I don't play, because some days its just fun to hop in, say hello to my guild, kill a few things, bake a couple of loaves of bread, and then go on about my day.The game features 17 unique classes, all with strengths and weaknesses, healing or tank, positioning or dps, and mixtures of both. Not gender locked, lots of cosmetics to buy, emotes to find, places to explore, and all set in an open-world environment (For grinding mobs). There are a handfull of big "Quests" to do at certain levels such as 50, 100, 110, etc that will boost you a few levels.Heroes system allowing to play 3 classes/combos at once. Guild level up system, pvp (Haha don't), and a few other things you'd come to expect quality of life wise like teleports and lore. While the game is not pay to win, the premium sub makes this "easier" to deal with. The typical 30% "faster" for premium sub, but if you don't want to invest, you can still eventually get there...albeit in a car with one flat tire.I have stockholme syndrome, its a terrible drug. =/

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Great game, fairly addictive.Addictive how? I don't know how to explain. It's just a personal preference thing.If you enjoy games that are slow and casual, you'll want to try this out.You'll spend most of your time harvesting resources you'll probably end up selling.The combat itself is turn-based, so that's self-explanatory. If you want a fast-paced game, you're looking at the wrong place.The first 12 levels or so, you'll find yourself with a bunch of interesting quests, but pretty much after that the story kinda disappears. I've only played till lvl 50, but so far I haven't had any storyline quest after the intro.At any rate, the most appealing factor of this game is probably its style and art. The grind itself isn't hectic, but farming for resources might break your sanity.Personally, I think this might be more of a social game.Also, this game has no problem showing animals mating.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												Hello all! Finny posting here, some of you who are reading this might want a brief review, some of you might just be looking at another Hardcore Wakfu players opinion so I'll give both. Played hours here 600 odd actual? 3.3k (no life)1st things 1st, this game is extremely unique i've never played a game like this, a game like this is truly amazing and so is the fact that the game is available on the Mac platform (what i'm using). TLDR: Game is amazing but VERY VERY grind-y, lonely and un-sociable (Read bottom paragraph). Would recommend :]Story: This is extremely limited, this is newbie friendly but is very short and only links to Ogrest which is still yet to be incorporated into the game (I think this was going to be level 200 content) once you progress to mid 100 content (level 50) the newely revamped islands (currently 2 out of 5-6+) you then get new quest-lines which feature ways to get Kamas (In game money) quicker through even more exploration of the game, this is tedious but can be fun for people who are casual and don't mind spending 20 hours+ running around the game. The story then jutters and jumps to mid game content (level 100, 118, 120 and 125) these questlines again feature kama making methods and are EXTREMELY fun and give an insight into the story of the game and the Ultimate Bosses (weekly bosses, sadly no challenge what-so-ever) you then have the section of the game which is the most grindy, intensive, game quit feeling inducing moment ever, this is the jump from 120 to the next 140 quest, this is the most boring and lonely grind experience ever, this puts most people off the game. From here you have more quests more frequently and you would have probably found a guild and start to have some online Wakfu friends, you then lead into the high level content, I won't speak about this since you'll probably have a basic understanding of the game and some good friends etc.Guilds: This is all down to preference but the size of the guilds aren't huge and you are basically forced into high level guilds just to see anyone online, there are a few English guilds which are really nice and newbie friendly (notice how I said few, it really is hardly any guilds that are newbie friendly) when entering this game it's not advised to ask high levels for leeching I will give you a quick run down of why:XP is grindy as HECKYou'll be on 0.5-0.75x XP meaning that someone grinding you a few levels will feel like a life time, period.Fun factorIs it fun for high levels? Yes and No, depends on their mood and what you're like as a player etc.Language Barrier Hit and miss remember this game is multi-cultural so be wary of whom you ask for help due to language barriers!In game revenue / money methodThis is called 'Kamas' you gain some each fight and with chests that you open from completing a respective Questline, this is tedious but you get quite a lot of money, awesome! On Remington you have quite a nice economy meaning that while some items are crazy high they are endgame and so you'll only aim for these once you have complete knowledge of the game and dungeons etc. Majority of other high level stuff is dirt cheap so that's cool!Dungeons:Fun and grindy you don't have to run it 1,000 time for an item to have 1 chance of dropping it but instead....! You can run it 1,000 times to get enough tokens to buy it huzzzah! So it's all down to your opinion, there's also major awesome guides online showing you how to complete these dungeons as-well as other players that you'll be running with experience!PvP:Completely broken due to only a select amount of classes being revamped and overly powerful, unless you follow the crowd with new classes i'd advise against it.Classes: Old ones are much weaker and often not taken/ accepted as much in dungeons compared to newer classes, same with other games but sad really R.I.P Sadida ;w;Bugs:This game has a fair amount of bugs in it but these seem to be ironed out fairly quickly, until recently where dupers have been duping end game items and selling them for very low prices, this has in turn kinda ruined the economy and the player base due to not trusting the market and other players, a lot of people such as my self feel slightly cheated that new people pick it 1-4 of these duped 20million each relics and I spent months farming 1 worth 4 million... This is a major problem as of May 26th 2015 so if you're reading the review take this into account!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												I loved Final Fantasy Tactics A2 and the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series and always wished for a multiplayer version of those games. This game does a pretty good job of putting the combat experiences of those games in a multiplayer setting. Besides the combat, I also enjoyed the game's environmental mechanics because it kind of gives me a Harvest Moon or Animal Crossing kind of vibe where the world gives you these resources to do things with, and the players are responsible for tending to them or making something out of them. As for the grinding, I personally don't know if it is actually necessary or not, but in any case I managed to skip the first story quests altogether and head to my chosen nation (Bonta) and then proceeded to grind the highest level mobs and dungeons that I could manage, purely because I love overwhelming myself in these tactics games and barely pulling through. It also helps that the only punishment for death is no exp gain for a lost battle, reduced stats for about 3 minutes and a respawn back to the previous checkpoint area of your choosing. I've spent no money on the game so far, but I might in the future if I keep playing. Paying players get some nice bonuses, but I've been playing comfortably without them. There's also some nifty costumes and stuff too. I recommend the game because it's free and I enjoy it. If you get it, I'd definitely recommend doing the tutorial and trying out a few different classes. I went through a couple classes and then went with the Elitrope as my main because I personally loved the portal mechanic. My brother went with the archer because he loved the obscene range and then the huppermage because of the elemental/light attack dynamic. There's a lot of variety, so don't be afraid to try a few out. Also, your lower level alts will gain an experience multiplier to make grinding levels faster,

Posted: October 30, 2015
												I have been playing this game off and on (mostly on) since 2012. I more than likely have thousands of hours of gameplay which I think is more than enough to warrant me to review it. And yet... reviewing this is hard. The game itself conceptually and artistically is fantastic. It is such a visually pleasing game and the music is pretty great too (after a while I put the music on mute however). You can really feel the thousands of hours of hand drawn work that went into making Wakfu such an attractive game. But the two caveats here is that the game is buggy and the customer support is lackluster at best. But before you turn away and never touch this game - just give it a shot. The game itself is good enough and challenging enough that you might really take to it. If you loved those JRPGs with the word 'tactics' thrown onto the end (or front like 'tactics ogre') of their titles then you might really fall for this game. What is more is that it is an MMO and as anyone who has really dug deep into an mmo knows you start to form bonds with these people that you play with. It is really unlike any experience a video game can provide.

I'll be truthful, the character design is extremely pleasing and creative, gameplay is. . . alright I suppose. The issues I found, though not playing it long (for a reason), is that there's very little ambience. It gives the game an eerie feeling. . ? I mean sure there's bright colours and I can turn on my own music but besides loading screens, don't expect too much sound unless you enter a fight and EVEN THEN there's no battle music to submerge you in it. Also, besides quests I didn't see much else to do. . . Better level up!! Since there's not much else to do!  The other issue I found was that I made a character and DID the tutorial and leveled to almost level 10 in one night (which isn't difficult trust me, there's plenty of enemies). I quit the game EXPECTING IT SAVED PROGRESS that I could come back to, but INSTEAD when I reopened the game it's as if my character or rogress EXISTED in the first place. I even used the same character names and everything! So, I had to redo the entire tutorial and everything. Yes because that's my favourite part of an MMO. . . If I even open the game again and my character was deleted once more I can gaurantee that I will be furious. There's no "save" option or is it just ever so hidden away that I can't locate it. . ?Anyways, to put it simply:Character design - HighGraphics - HighGameplay - Medium to lowOverall - an OK game, if you need to pass time.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												* CaveatsFirst of all, the caveats.  If you can't handle these, don't bother:** Partial pay-to-winBonus XP and loot abound alongside otherwise-unatainable items for those who open their wallet.  I wouldn't call it a true pay-to-play since it's entirely possible to compete with people who pay, but it will take significantly more effort on your end.  The items may even make sense in some cases if they're cheap enough, but I would never recommend to anyone the booster pack or paying continuous fees for the new hero system  It's preposterous unless you have far too much money and nothing better to do with it.** SlowTactical, turn-based combat that gives everyone 30 seconds to make their move.  With up to twelve players per battle (6 players per team PvP), there can be something of a wait until your turn.  For me, this is an advantage since I can plan out my approach more carefully, or even do other things while playing (the game makes a distinct sound when it's your turn), but people who prefer action will find it a bit troublesome.** ConfusedWakfu sometimes wants to straddle the line between single player and MMO.  The scenes when following the main questline definitely try to feel like you're playing through a single player RPG, and those other players with you are all extras.  You, yes, you are the hero of prophecy, and it is your task alone to defeat Ogrest.  It's a neat approach, but the disconnect is sometimes a bit much.** TrollsDon't like being randomly killed by someome three times your level?  Might not be your game.  The only way to completely opt out of PvP is to stay in Astrub, where you'll never be able to level far.  Honestly, this doesn't happen often.  Once every couple months or so, it seems to happen to me.  The consequences of losing are pretty miniscule -- You reappear at your phoenix and there's a negative status effect attached to you for three minutes.  My suggestion is generally to ignore them because of this, but some people have strong emotional reactions to this, so they should be aware.** PerformanceMy laptop is hardly top of the line, but it plays a number of my games with no problem.  It doesn't even slow down much on Minecraft most of the time, and we know how badly that was coded.  Why, then, does this 2d game sometimes completely tank in framerate even when the graphics settings are at the minimum?  Why can it then run quite well sometimes with the graphics set to max?  There's a wide variation possible based on what's happening at the time, both visually (there was a problem with the steam/smoke effect a few months ago that brought both machines I used Intel cards on to their knees, while my significantly older Radeon didn't suffer at all) and in terms of action (beginning and ending battles, loading areas, players suddenly logging in, etc. can sometimes leave Wakfu unresponsive for seconds on my laptop), so if your machine is fairly weak, prepare for occasional input or display lag.** DocumentationMy goodness.  There are tutorial panels that come up occasionally to try to tech you what's going on.  Some of them are massively outdated, some aren't descriptive enough to be much help, some come up at bad times and block your view, or even mouse (Though most can be dismissed with a click, I encountered one that could not.), at awkward times.  Frequently, the best option is to ask someone.* The restNow, on to the good stuff:** Class selectionThere are a variety of classes that can represent a significant range in play styles.  The classes I love the most aren't neccessarily liked by my friends as I do not always like theirs, which I generally take to be a good thing on variety.  Even within classes, there are a surprising number of variants available based on the spells you choose to bring to battle and where you spent your points when leveling.  There are some respec opportunities available for free (as well as one for cash and one that requires you to collect a rather shocking amount of items), and it's relatively easy to level a character once you learn where to go and what to kill (so you can even discard a character and redo it all if you don't feel it's worth earning a respec).** Fun combat systemIt's not the best system I've ever seen (Makai Kingdom forever, man!), but the combat system is remarkably nice.  With the recent update, you are limited in the number of spells/abilities you can bring to battle.  This has significantly hampered one of my characters, who was a staunch generalist, but it has helped refine a few others.  The spells, active abilities, passive abilities, and attributes of your character are genuinely brought to life by a combat system that effectively allows you to translate your choices during character growth into sometimes novel and interesting results in combat.  It then goes further by offering additional challenges in combat that you can complete for bonus XP and items.  If you decide to go along with it, these can sometimes make a battle much more interesting.  Even enemies notably weaker than you can get complicated when you refuse to give up on any of the challenges, which can be a delightful way to keep things interesting when you need to gather items dropped by weak enemies.** GraphicsThe anime-style graphics are generally well done, with good customization for your character's appearance (Your equipment appears on your character, allowing for great flexibility in appearance if you're not too worried about having great equipment, or you can use costumes to hide it and choose freely.) and relatively fluid animation that feels quite right when put together.** StoryThe story itself is pretty generic, but it's realized in a remarkably nice universe with solid backstory and a wide varity of interesting characters.  Suffice it to say the world has a great feel to it.** CommunityYeah, I mentioned trolls earlier.  They definitely exist, and there's no real way to control or contain them implemented.  They're a small portion of the population, though.  Some of the conversations and interactions between players are hilarious or intriguing, there's a wide variety of emotes to unlock, and even text smilies are brought to life with the vizage  of your character doing the expression above your head.  There's plenty of people to talk with, and sometimes random people just feel like inviting you to join their group.  Being an introvert myself, I was rather cautious at first, but I've grown rather fond of people randomly inviting me to go stomp through a dungeon or two with them, or to do a bit of this or that quest line with them.  It's really rather fun.** TypesA bit of a note, the options available to players are a bit more vaired and detailed then Healer, Tank, DPS.  Obviously, there will be damage specialists sometimes, but they can specialize on distance or close combat if they can afford to sacrifice the other, there will also be those who specialize on moving allies or enemies to different spaces in the field to maximize the advantage for their side, characters who can use a great number of status effects on friend and foe alike, characters that place blockages on the field to keep enemies where you want them or who scatter automated turrets or summoned allies across the field to win with sheer numbers...  If you're expecting battle to always be straightforward, you're in for a surprise.* ConclusionWhile I hate some of the free-to-play nonsense, and I mourn the great potential the hero system had before it became the rent-a-slot deal it is, I have a great deal of respect for the effort and thought that has shaped this game into the remarkable thing it currently is.  I enjoy Wakfu a lot, and many of my fellow fans of tactical turn-based combat will likely come to the same conclusion should they give it a long enough try.  I wholeheartedly recommend Wakfu to those who enjoy a good turn-based tactical fight.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												This game is a fantastic amount of fun, even compared to many other tripple-A titles. It has a way of easing you into the gameplay and system that fealt like the right ammount of hand-holding and freedom to make mistakes. I do understand that Wakfu or it's parent game Dofus are not for everyone. It being on the turn based and tactical side of MMO's it does take the right fit for a gamer to enjoy. That being said however if you are new to turn based tactical RPG's and want to give them a try, this game will not let you down. It can work as an excellent introduction into the genre, and the community in this game has proven time and time again to be very welcoming to newcomers, and you will get every bit of assistance you could ask for.All things being equal, I would highly recommend this game to everyone who enjoys this genre of game and my personal overall score of this game would be around 8.5/10The flaws are few and not wanting to repeat what my fellow reviewers have said I will make a refrence a particular reviewer for his/her hard work and broad grasp of the game. Having read through the majority of the reviews the one I do most agree with is Myrtth's.Myrtth gives a fairly informative and detailed review of the game. Look her review and should give you every thing else you would want to know.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												So, I've played Wakfu for  2500 hours since open beta almost 6 years ago and i recommend this game.I find this MMORPG very fun to play although it does has its downsides to. So here are some pros and cons:Pros:- Its realy fun to play if you are the strategic kinda type and like to take your time (Turn-based)- The Community in-game is realy friendly and almost always helpfull since pvp isnt a big or esential part of the game.- Theres lots of diffrent quests to do, Profesions to be leveled, Dungeons to run, people to hang out with, collectibles to be found and tons of other stuff.- Lots of different character classes to choose from for your own playstyle (right now its about 18 (both male and female))Cons:- Wakfu has its fair share of bugs, these are mostly minor but still iritating (also steam achievements seemed to progress slower or not at all when they should be (this is on 22-07-2016).- It has a lack of tutorials, hints do apear but theres nothing to solid, although there are lots of Guilds in Astrub (main beginners region) that are always looking for new members and are willing to help out.- All the things thrown at you can be pretty overwhelming at first, but you probably know a lot more around lvl 50 (can be achieved in less then 5 hours if power leveld so depends how u look at it)I WONT recommend this game for people that can't get along with others very well and are the leeroy jenkins kinda type.I DO recommend this game if you are looking for something for the long run with lots of stuff to do, friends to be made, and strategic fun the be had.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Wakfu is a tactical MMORPG unlike any other MMO except for its prequel, Dofus.  It has play style similar to Final Fantasy Tactics where combat takes place in a grid. The character classes (15 of them) in Wakfu (and Dofus) have unique play styles and the classes themselves can be played many different ways.The spells have a variety of rules, and positioning makes a big factor in damage dealt/recieved.The art in this game is very charming.  It's very pleasing to just look at the content in the game.The music is very pleasing as well.  All from playful, cheery music to serious, blood-pumping music.There is a lot of humor in this game and a lot of funny parodies.  A lot of naughty references are in the game too, but are subtle enough that kids wouldn't (or shouldn't) understand.Of course, playing in a team with others is a lot of fun (and often necessary for tackling dungeons of your lvl).  Being in a guild & the in-game group finder tool helps with playing with others to enjoy the game better.Players can also make an impact on the environment.  Most mobs can be planted to have them spawn, and they can also be killed enough to have very little to no population in the area (sometimes ghost forms appear when that happens). Flowers, Trees, and crops can also be planted in the world and are shared with others, and they can also be completely harvested with none left for others.  Making certain plant/mob population too high or too low or just right can affect area bonuses and nation bonuses.  One nation (Riktus) benefits from other nations having their bonuses ruined.The environment, plus nation laws and wars set by a governor voted by its citizens (who then can appoint other people to different positions in government), makes for interesting experiences in the world.I've been playing this game for a long time (since open beta Jan 2012).  It's enjoyable and I recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												This is my experience of finding Wakfu.I really love a legendary game Final Fantasy, all of them. but the most I personally like, is the tactic. I played it on every game station it has. Started on PSX, then Lion War on PSP came out, I even installed emulator so i can play on my phone. Thats how much i Loved it. The Grid-Based battle. The Story written. The Plot. The Character classical grinding process. The Class complexity and lots of skills each of them have.  The Game was simply.. perfect.Until I reach a point where I want to explore another great game with same criteria. I try a lot of games, not very satisfying. Sometime the battle was not good, the story not interesting, too easy. it always lack of something, that tend to makes me stop playing. "Maybe  FFT is the best game after all." Thats exactly my thought at the time.Then, I found Wakfu.It was an RPG. MMO at its best. Grid-Based Battle, and Free roaming. Various Character you could choose to play with and the complexity of each character skills, is remarkable. It has profession system, side quest like. A Guild, Nation, Outlaw, and environmental system. Also, It has many secret too. I found several secret places that even havent used. I saves several and upload on my profile. It has so many element that hasnt been implemented, yet the game was this much interesting.Long story short, this game is worth your time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												I really want to like this game.  I mean I REALLY want to like it.  There are a few things preventing me from giving my full life to this game.-Pros--Great design and look-Unique classes-Interesting skills (more on this later)-If you like tactical RPGs and MMOs then this is probably for you.-Cons--VERY complicated for a beginner to get into. (this seems to be a theme)-Not very beginner friendly, most things have to be explained by long-time players within the game.-Skills are horribly explained, skill buffs/beduffs are explained in pop-ups within pop-ups within pop-ups at times.-Very convoluted texts and quests.-Some things such as haven bags, setting a location, and professions aren't explained very well at all.-Unexplained reasoning for actions having to be taken by the player, such as HAVING to have a respec at lvl 10 or you cannot fight anything in the game, ever.  If this is a bug of some kind, it should be stated as such by the developer.  Otherwise, it's quite jarring to suddenly realize you can no longer battle anything in the game.Again, this game is great and has wonderful depth to the classes and skill sets, but the convoluted execution of it all does not create a well-thoughtout package for beginners.  The tutorial in the beginning leaves much to be desired and only prepares the player for the battles.  Everything else in the game has to be found out, missed, or learned through other longtime players in the game.I still recommend trying this game out and see if you are willing to spend the time necessary to learn all of what it has to offer.  I'm still learning as I go, gaining a little bit more knowledge as time goes on through other players.  It's a slow going process but it might pay off in the depth and fun to be had.

												It's a shame that you don't see much turn-based combat in MMOs anymore, especially when it's done so well, like in Wakfu. Really, there's a lot of great mechanics in the game that are super unique and fun to play around with, but the game is pretty empty sometimes and there's no real questline structure past the early areas. You're kind of just released into the world to grind, and while the combat is unique, it's really personal preference as to how fun it is. Overall, the most innovative MMO I've ever played, though innovative doesn't necessarily mean outstanding.
