number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I'm honestly torn how to rate this game. Love the community, hate the developers. Beautiful art too!My opinions are based off of roughly May, 2015. Some of this may have changed. Most probably hasn't.--History, Positives about the game--I played the title since beta v0.2 and loved the class system, was intrigued by the "no NPCs" rule (except territory masters), LOVED that original crafting system, and LOVED the open (grid based) world where you could plant resources anywhere you wanted or cut everything down! >:D However, everything was in French. I learned a lot of French.Then they remade it (beta v0.3) with English support. I kept playing but the crafting system was replaced with a typical gather-craft grind. Still great open-world sandbox game. They added more classes so combat was more interesting, guilds developed. The community was super great, with a handful of ... inciting personalities.Time is getting muddled in my brain, but somewhere in there we reached full 12 (then 13, then 14...) classes, Wakfu "left beta", it was released on Steam, EA signed on to manage the North American server, quests developed, guilds developed even further, and much more area, mechanics, and equipment were added into the game. Good things.--Drawbacks--However, I have never been part of a game where the developers were more sluggish in responding to the people.Patches come once a month at best. Sometimes three months pass without a change. Then BOOM everything is changed, a few barely noticable hotfixes in the days that follow, then, silence.They have a terrible tendency to balance a class around PvP OR PvE. Never both. (Also, huge favortism with developers and certain classes they work on. Trying to outdo one another?)Classes have gone unbalanced for AGES and developers would rather wait years to remake the class entirely rather than tune some numbers. Sometimes these class changes completely gut the core identity of a class.Example time!Eniripsas (healers, my preferred main) went TWO YEARS with both a mechanic that made healing more effective (by flat bonus per spell) and less effective (by scaled percentage) in long fights. Two mechanics that fought each other.They didn't tune numbers. They didn't get rid of the passive that was the issue. They took the power of the class (extending fights) and made it impossible to do so because a good healer couldn't die in 1v1 pvp fights.A completely wrong reaction to a legitimate problem. SELF heals could have been nerfed at any time.Xelors were (are?) the time-mage class. They focus on removing your enemies ability to use as many skills on their turn. However, certain PvE bosses came out and Xelors could keep them from doing any damage.So, first they made a stacking resist occur every time Xelors were successful. ON ALL MONSTERS AND PLAYERS. (Whats the point of being punished for doing your classes job?) They later made those same PvE bosses immune to AP loss and increased both the max AP and spell cost and thus rendered the point moot, yet kept the scaling resist on everything else.But I digress...A rock-paper-scissors PvP system where there are 3-4 reigning classes at any one time, each with 0-2 classes it just cannot fight and win.A confusing swap from solo play being the focus, to full group of six players being the only way to get good experience, back to allowing solo players to fake the group dynamic with bought upgrades.--Summary--All in all I had some good times playing Wakfu with a huge guild (shoutout to Kamaradery!). The wonder of it wore off and I realized the mismanagement of the game.So, this game will entertain you and can bring you a lot of fun. Until you experience most of the content and start waiting for the developers. Then, only sadness.I truly wish the best for Wakfu in the future because it has some amazing pieces that I want to see in other games. However, I dont think I can play it any more. The people that made it great have moved on and so should I.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Dofus was the brainchild of Ankama, a unique and very imaginative strategy based MMO, y'know with the final fantasy tactics kind of gameplay. It featured a pretty huge world with unique enemies on nearly every zone and map, with many freaking dungeons to enter as a team of unique races, each with their own set of abilities that all contribute to your chances of clearing these dungeons.Wakfu is supposed to be the sequel MMO to the world of Dofus, the world is flooded because of Ogrest, an ogre who swallowed a dofus, which in dofus, was the most rare and expensive thing in the world of twelve.You can play 14 classes, same as in Dofus, each race has been graphically updated or changed a little.What wakfu did right is that it tried to create a world that was entirely run by its players, environments and even the 4 divided nations are still entirely run by players, with its own governors, vice governors, treasurer, eco protector, guards, soldiers, activity chiefs you name it. From the tree's to the monsters its all provided by the player themselves.which is also exactly why its greatest and most unique feature is also its worst.Imagine the average lazyMMO player destroying an entire ecosystem you as a player worked really hard to preserve within an hour? it actually costs money from the treasury (who you pay your taxes to) to patch up, annoying right?imagine an item on the market you want with incredibly high taxes to go with it.better vote for a different governor next time, what's that? You didn't know you could? Well you can!Every week or month (can't remember) there's elections for a new governor, even you can become one. With enough votes you'll win and you can put your own friends in charge of handling various government jobs in your nation.you can even declare WAR on the other nations and allow your nation's people to attack visitors from the other nations on sight.with this system though it's easily abused by guilds and stuff funneling their votes into a guild master or whatever, which is too bad. Combat is a little more fast paced which I find sad really. Bosses can be very fun to fight in a grup though.The classes themselves feel a little like dumbed down versions of their Dofus ancestors, you'll only be using maybe 6 or so abilities through your entire playthrough.It's still worth checking out as its free to play, and I still do recommend you play it. It's artstyle is incredibly nice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Ah wakfu, what can I say about this game that can't be limited to pros and cons? Not a lot, so we'll just do pros and consPros Unique gameplay Interesting lore Simple pet system Relatively friendly community Well made guild system Professions Wide variety to pick from class wise Playing more than one account is encouragedCons Boosters are needed to compete later levels Extremely grindy After the free resets the game gives you it is a huge pain to do a quest for resets P2w for days. The Steam client for this game isn't as good as the one you can get off the game site Holiday events are usually crap.  Bugs tend to not get fixed for months at a time  Neglectful devs are neglectfulBoth pro & conI had to include this because there are things in this game that really could be amazing if used correctly or actual work be put into them. Political system - corrupt as all hades, suggesting removing it until they put work on it Ecosystem - players tend to be the biggest problem with this, nobody wants to replant...ect... Forced pvp - You have to pvp to protect your nation for the most part but even if you aren't in a pvp mode anyone and their best friend can bum rush and kill you for no other reason then being a donkey. Class reworks - classes were nerfed so hard into the ground they have to rework all of them but hey atleast you get shiny new spells Cosemtics - Cosemtics are actually pretty cool and let you make your character look great. This is only the case if you don't spend real money, otherwise be prepared to pay $20 for a piece of crap you can't trade.Wakfu brings an interesting twist on turn based combat and MMORPGs. Try it, if you don't like it just delete it and never speak of the horrors mechanics again.TL;DR Don't download with steam if you want more than one account5/10 without booster 8/10 with

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												--Edit--As of the update to 1.43 myself as well as several other people I've talked to in-game have not been able to purchase the in-game currency for their shop (Ogrines). I attempted to report the issue to Ankama support but they were rude and dismissive, sending me to Steam support saying my account was being restricted per the "Trading and Market Restrictions" (found at https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=1047-EDFM-2932 ).I forwarded them a screenshot of my purchase history and explained how this policy did not affect me based on my purchase history. They responded with this:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Please accept our sincerest apologies.However, we have already endorsed this case to a higher level of customer support. Unfortunately, they have made their decision and have stated it as final. Therefore, we are unable to reverse it or force a different outcome. We understand that decision is not according to your expectations.As per our previous message, we are unfortunately not able to provide you more assistance on this issue.For a breakdown of the new purchase restrictions enforced by Steam, they are as follows:+Steam accounts are not allowed any purchase unless they had a successful purchase older than 30 days but not older than 1 year.+The successful purchase (meaning the transaction was not cancelled or refunded) of wallet funds, games, DLCs and software meet this requirement.+Retail CD key activations and gift purchases do not meet this requirement and will not lift the purchase restrictions on a Steam account.Please opt to contact the Steam Customer Support for further assistance. Apologies for the inconvenience.Kind regards,------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I will update this review whenever I get the problem solved, but as for now I am at my wits end. I cannot recommend the game until they show better commitment to solving (at least) paying customer's issues in a timely manner.--Edit End--I love this game. It's artwork is amazing, It has an almost entirely player driven world from the ecosystem to nations ruled by PCs. Wars are fought as much through ecoterrorism as face to face combat. There are a multitude of guilds which fill in gameplay between storyline quests (if the national dramas aren't enough!) The system can be a bit buggy as stated in previous reviews but no-where near the point where the game loses playability. It is turn-based but there is also a turn timer which keeps things moving fairly well. The classes don't quite use traditional roles (tank, dps, healer, ect.) per say. In many cases you CAN build your character to strictly fill one of these roles and you'll find tons of guides on the Ankama forums to help you do so. That being said, MOST classes you can build to fill one or two roles successfully or a well rounded solo character that has just as good playability and balance in a group filling a role.The game is great, it gets monthly updates, it blends with an anime that even further immerses you into the World of Twelve. And it's highly addictive. 10/10 all around. Give it a shot and you'll be hooked!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Ok, for real?I spent a good year or so playing this game, developing a guild, making some great new friends. But if I were to be absolutely critical, this is my review:Wakfu is a strategy MMO with a battle system remniscent of games such as Final Fantasy Tactics. It features several unique classes, a world with a rich story and lore comparable to Warcraft's, and a fun, playful art style you could probably only find from a French game.Its parent company, Ankama, has recently put in a lot of work to developing the earlier game (levels 1-100, basically) but overall... you basically need to be social in order to have fun with this game. Without friends, without a guild, the grinding can get pretty boring pretty quick. Further, the community is small and the PVP a little under developed - a recipe for disaster. Overall, I would still recommend this game, but with a huge grain of salt. If you can get past the grinding, the "highschool" mentality of the social scene, and the dupers, its pretty fun!  FOR THE GLORY OF BRAKMAR!6.5/10, I guess.

												First of all most games that you can play these days are easy mode meaning it doesn't take much to get to the end game.  Most F2P games ask you to spend everything you have to get ahead, including the shirt on your back. This game isn't either. It takes a lot of effort to level up and everyone is equal (not P2W). It's well balanced with good graphics and music. It even has some humor in it to make you laugh. So if you want a game to take your mind off things (spend hours out of reality and beat things up to exact your fustration), need a good laugh, see graphics that are pleasing to the eye, and maybe even feel like dancing to good tunes then this game is for YOU! It's a well balanced turn based game so some may not like it but for those who like or even love turn based games then give this a try. What will it hurt?? :-)

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												A really great game that very few people have heard about. It has a unique style of combat in the MMO-verse: turn-based. The good thing is, it's pretty quick considering the turn-based nature of it. The community seems pretty good, maybe a bit on the younger side of things (majority under 25 is my guess), but that's not been a negative for me (almost 30). For those who are inclined to get deep into the game, there is a political system for each of the four nations, as well as an in-depth weather system that ties into the ecosystem for each nation.The graphics are totally awesome; it has a top-down view, similar to that of Ultima Online or Dark Ages (Nexon).It's definitely worth a go if you're looking for something free and detailed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												-the time played is of course false, Id say I've spent about 150 hours in game? -********** INTRODUCTION - A BIT OF HISTORY ***********Now I was a player of Wakfu back in the day (in 2012, like everyone here) and frankly the game was good. now sure, I had to pay a monthly fee (that was not nearly as much as what WoW would ask you to pay, but still, I had to pay it), but the game itself was great. The problem was that unfortunately, the servers were devoid of players, because most wakfu players would have been Dofus players and I think that the beta of Wakfu did really badly with tons of bugs etc. So I eventually dropped the game, like GW2, if you want, and went for something else. You cannot guess how surprised I was to see this game coming on steamplay xD.Well, I for one think that this is the best thing Ankama (french gaming company who did Dofus and Wakfu) could have done. Byt doing this not only will their number of players multiply by 100 (it was that low) but the game will be revived. As I understand it, now, there is no need for monthly payment (which I find is great) and you can just enjoy a great game for free.***********     THE REVIEW AT THE STATE THE GAME WAS IN 4 MONTHS AGO    ***********                       ( not much has changed except for an extra playable character )Now I keep saying great game, but what makes this game so great? many, many things.I think the first word to describe this game would be innovative, it is struggling to do something no MMO has ever done.+ Everyone has their own player house FROM THE BEGINNING and it can be upgraded and decorated through quests, achievements and dungeon battles.+ It has a very extensive job system. (it really is, trust me, you don't?  prepare to cut wood, fish, kill monsters, create monsters, plant trees, plant herbs/pick herbs, cereals (not the same skill tree), mine, craft potions, food and drink, weapons and armor, and bags and even house decorations. Each job comes with a skill tree which when ugraded allows you to pick and plant more resources/ make better gear.+ A very advanced ecosystem if all you do is cut a certain type of tree and no one else around you is planting some, prepare to be sued by the government for being anti ecologist. I also strongly advise not to cut down endangered species as that WILL lower your citizenship rating and you will eventually become an outlaw. Your chances of succesfully planting a plant will be mitigated by the weather, some plants like it sunny, others not so much.+ And to follow up on that point, an extremely well thought out political system. There is a government for each faction (there are four) on each server, in which there is a governor, and maybe 6-7 ministers (defence, ecology, economy, war... ). The governor's job is mainly two things, to go to war and to decide whih laws are in place or not. There are maybe 30 laws that can be turned off or on and that affect the daily life of the citizenry. The political system is extremely important because the government itself will organise events, and issue the tax levels on the different areas of the game. The government can spend the money gained this way in different ways: to control the weather in some areas, to edict new laws, to organise more events...+ War can be declared between factions, following that will be a grand scale battle between the said factions to conquer islands that aren't their home ones, knowing that a conquered island comes with benefits for the controlling faction.+ A Great strategic battle system which encourages you to be more tactical and not button spam like most MMO these days. there are 15  (originally there were twelve, then there were 14, and after I stopped playing they added in another one so 15) classes, each with a different skillset and abilities.+ A great variety of monsters who are also affected by the ecosystem. You can collectfrom species and then use it to spawn new monsters into the world.Well, thats all I can think of for the good points, now to the negative points-  Back in the day, each class was nerfed or augmented every day, which made for a very hazy game experience, I do not know if they still do that however I doubt that they have yet found the perfect balance between the 14 characters (now 15) as there are always some who will outperform the rest.-  In game shop. Not much to say here, i'm just putting it here because that's basically a negative aspect of any game and yes there are some things you can get from the shop that make you more powerful, so it's NOT just cosmetic, but its really not indispensable.- Still some occasionnal bugs, but nothing major.- There is a main story, but it is completely seperated from the rest of the game for some unknown reason. I would have preferred a story implemented in the rest of the game.-/+ The lack of actual quests can be a bit annoying at first but I guess the presence of dynamic events (like in guild wars 2) makes it a bit better.Yeah so I guess that's it, I hope you read it all and that it was helpful. Of course don't try this if you hate turn based strategy, but if you don't, even if you're not sure after reading my review, just try it, it's free ;)******************** WHAT IS HAPPENING NOW ********************Unfortunately Ankama doesnt give aabout it's French player base (when we are the ones who have been supporting the game for 2 years) and does not let french accounts (like mine) play the game from Steam at all when Steam is the place to play it because of the newly found international playerbase. I think this is a stupid and  move and I am forced to thumbs down this game because of this. The game itself is still loved, but I cant thumbs up a game I can't play.***********************UPDATE AS OF 20/02 ************************Ankama FINALLY stopped their t! It took them 2 years! but now the game is finally free to play for all!! (changing my review form negative to positive as a result)  :D

Great!. Then read on and prepare for a completly random review.The gameplay is turn based grid based game with all the stragrindy of having higher numbers then what ever misshappen remixed abomination from kinder children on acid with some slang swears and lewd sexual content only those within the teenage and dirty mind will understand type of creatures.Armed with all the spells you could want "about 15 total for each class 20 for huppermage" that allows diverse switching of tactics with a wide arsenal of elemental attacks "3 of whice you will actually use".With a job system that takes for f**king ever to amount to anything and minor cases of Ptsd Ocd and emotinal stress of watching your waifu endure endless in what ever mundane task you can think of from planting trees cutting wheat to mineing fixed placed self regenerting material blocks for ores "most of whice you will delete cause you just want to make money and its useless".With the classes being seperated into ones whice you play if you have friends and others if you don't become a one man army or a severaly crippled low level scrub that barely manages to get by in the worst and worlds most broken econamy since post obama.With all the weapon selection whice amp your abilitys you can increase even further... your abilitys! "no one actually uses weapons we just use them for stat boosts like armour, only use a weapon if you feel like wasteing time and showing off your sweet sweet swag".With the ability to grind Grind! GRIND!! you too can become a low level player still stuck around level 50 out of "200 i think" cause you have no f**king idea how to level up properly and there is no average guides worth reading after you have actually started the game and planned it all in advance.Beat up hapless monsters and make your way haphazardly through the world of... uh... grid based tile sets whice become a real pain to navigate as you will only be useing the mouse to move!, thats right DOTA fans, left click to move right for actions! "though in Dota its actually the other way around but really who cares?".Join up with a dwindling community as we try to uphold the game with all the minor and worthless value it has and is waiting for!, play for a few days, take break for a few months, repeat again and again as the replay value "nothing" becomes so boring you actually have more fun not playing the  game!.But for those who are persistant, brave, and or have no lives, come play with us, where we will completly ignore you as were to busy trying to work around the absolutely horrible player priceing commonly found in Mmo's but with less players and rarer gear worth even more!.It has some good sides but iv forgetten half of them and can't be bothered with minor details, really its a typical Mmo all things considered its small it runs well and it does have an enjoyment factor though you will find it much greater if you have some friends decide to roll play or not and actually work together, apart from that you will find yourself feeling lonely like many other Mmo's where even in the busiest market places no one actually bothers to openly sell stuff "except outside a giant church in neutral territory cause you will want to collect your token each day you log in".This in its own way could be counted as a beutiful flawed master piece, and if they fixed some $hit it would be even better and attract more players thus enchancing the game, but its made in french... france. Sacr blu its one of those two!. So good luck trying to suggest anything to the devs.Waifu. I mean Wakfu! - 6.5/10

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												Wakfu is not a game; its a lifestyle.  where your actions effect the whole of a mmo world. there is many things you can do, from crafting or performing a profession such as armorer, or farming. or defeating dungeons useing a tactical rpg format. after 2 overhauls of the way skills work and how stats are effected, the game is more balanced.  in addition to skills making more sence, and easy to upgrade them from lvling. i like the feature of the haven bag/world. haveing your own extra storage that you can carry along with you; customize with bedroom sets, garden gems(for growing stuff), and crafting tables-so you can do professions or craft on the go/collect and save plants for later use. what i dont like is that the official site gives more buyable options-even though donation rewards overall dont overpower your progression over others in any big or lasting way. i would like the option to change my name or get any of the other things steam wakfu shop doesnt have that official site shop does.       but after going over merit and flaw balance, then compared to other games of style type or what is available during this era of gaming, i give it a 8/10.  and definately recommend other to pick it up and play it.

Posted: February 19, 2016
												I've played Dofus years ago and enjoyed every minute of it. I can say the same about Wakfu. There's a lot of freedom, fun and enjoyable content in this game. Turn based combat forces you to think alot about your moves and lets you plan your movement in the future turns. The world is huge and well done. Another feature that should be noticed is that there's no NPC shops. There's an auction house, where people create economy and dictate prices. I also enjoy profession and crafting system. I find leveling up my crafting/harvesting skills very enjoyable. All in all, I could talk a lot about this game, but you should try it for yourselves. After all, it's free to play.

												This is a free to play french MMORPG. There happens to be a very good tv show animation of it as well.Requirements are very low as its really 2d with an isometric (3d like) view, i think it runs on java.The battles are done by turn, in a square grid. It is fun and challenging as well.It has some original character classes and lore, and some of the usual. 												this game!!i am a final fantasy lover! i played all of them! (just to clear my point of view here)this game, it has lots of classes, with lots of differences!it has a class which lets you capture monsters to fight for you!!! (total win for me)you can just grind on monsters if you arent much into quests, you can level really well on those!so far, every single monster you fight, gives you its own equipment set o.o xD (sounds a bit like monster hunter? RIGHT!)kill a sheep! get a sheep equipment set, kill a pink bird, get a pink feather like set!i really love that ideayou can craft a LOT, you can run around, plant trees and flowers, sure other players will just take those trees or flowers away from the ground, but you can just replant them again if you got enough seedstry to make it YOUR world with YOUR pretty or ugly flowers! maybe the others wont be high enough gardener level to destroy your beautiful landscape idea XDwell okay, its mainly just ingredients for craftingif im not in the mood to fight monsters etc, ill just run around, take seeds from flowers and plant them all over the world to get my gardener level higher :Dbtw, you can even get .... ugh... monster seeds (i know, it does sound weird saying it that way)you can plant those seeds into the ground to grow your own monsters!but i think it only works in areas where those monsters actually are, you cant grow lv 20 monsters in the lv1 area (sad xD)IF you are a solo player and HATE teaming up with others like i do, you can just be weird, pay a bit of money in the cashop and be allowed to use 2 others of YOUR characters for your team, that way you have a 3 player team which you alone control, yes, you heard right, you can make up a team by yourself ;) perfect for anti-social people like me xD(it doesnt stay forever tho, its like 2 euro per week, cheaper if you buy it for longer, but i guess you know how that works)CON!1. the monster you capture, does NOT level up with you, it stays at the level where you capture it, which means, you wont be able to keep your favorite pet till high level because it will be really really weak then.... (really sad...)2. you cant keep your favorite look in the game because the set items get weak, there is no way to preserve the look of an item (as most other mmo's do) so you end up looking really ugly in the end because of 'high-stat-item-ugly-look' stuff

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Wakfu is built off the lore and mechanics of an old game called Dofus that used to run off flash. Then Amakna built Wakfu as a more modern version, with a slightly different side of the World of Twelve's story, as well as different take on character development. Overall this game has tremendous depth and complexity, even if its 2D interface can be a little off-putting.The game features many different character classes or races with basic attributes, which can be reinforced through leveling in countless different ways to suit whatever playstyle you may desire. In addition to combat there are also a rather extensive set of professions, that are accessible upon discovery and appropriately grindy towards end-game. The game's economy runs off a server-wide marketplace accessible from several different places around the World of Twelve.As a free to play game there is a wide array of microtransactions availbale ranging from cosmetics and accessories, to booster packs and "sidekicks". The game does a good job of keeping these things out of the combat system, so that a paying and free user can get into a fight and not notice any sort of difference in terms of their abilities.Overall the game is a lot of fun to play, and there are many ways to pair up with a companion or two, adding the additional spice to your fights. I do recommend the use of booster packs and other XP bonuses towards mid levels as character development seems to slow down drastically around level 60-70.Overall this is a pretty unique game, I recommend it if you want a change of scenery!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Ok, for real?I spent a good year or so playing this game, developing a guild, making some great new friends. But if I were to be absolutely critical, this is my review:Wakfu is a strategy MMO with a battle system remniscent of games such as Final Fantasy Tactics. It features several unique classes, a world with a rich story and lore comparable to Warcraft's, and a fun, playful art style you could probably only find from a French game.Its parent company, Ankama, has recently put in a lot of work to developing the earlier game (levels 1-100, basically) but overall... you basically need to be social in order to have fun with this game. Without friends, without a guild, the grinding can get pretty boring pretty quick. Further, the community is small and the PVP a little under developed - a recipe for disaster. Overall, I would still recommend this game, but with a huge grain of salt. If you can get past the grinding, the "highschool" mentality of the social scene, and the dupers, its pretty fun!  FOR THE GLORY OF BRAKMAR!6.5/10, I guess.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I'm honestly torn how to rate this game. Love the community, hate the developers. Beautiful art too!My opinions are based off of roughly May, 2015. Some of this may have changed. Most probably hasn't.--History, Positives about the game--I played the title since beta v0.2 and loved the class system, was intrigued by the "no NPCs" rule (except territory masters), LOVED that original crafting system, and LOVED the open (grid based) world where you could plant resources anywhere you wanted or cut everything down! >:D However, everything was in French. I learned a lot of French.Then they remade it (beta v0.3) with English support. I kept playing but the crafting system was replaced with a typical gather-craft grind. Still great open-world sandbox game. They added more classes so combat was more interesting, guilds developed. The community was super great, with a handful of ... inciting personalities.Time is getting muddled in my brain, but somewhere in there we reached full 12 (then 13, then 14...) classes, Wakfu "left beta", it was released on Steam, EA signed on to manage the North American server, quests developed, guilds developed even further, and much more area, mechanics, and equipment were added into the game. Good things.--Drawbacks--However, I have never been part of a game where the developers were more sluggish in responding to the people.Patches come once a month at best. Sometimes three months pass without a change. Then BOOM everything is changed, a few barely noticable hotfixes in the days that follow, then, silence.They have a terrible tendency to balance a class around PvP OR PvE. Never both. (Also, huge favortism with developers and certain classes they work on. Trying to outdo one another?)Classes have gone unbalanced for AGES and developers would rather wait years to remake the class entirely rather than tune some numbers. Sometimes these class changes completely gut the core identity of a class.Example time!Eniripsas (healers, my preferred main) went TWO YEARS with both a mechanic that made healing more effective (by flat bonus per spell) and less effective (by scaled percentage) in long fights. Two mechanics that fought each other.They didn't tune numbers. They didn't get rid of the passive that was the issue. They took the power of the class (extending fights) and made it impossible to do so because a good healer couldn't die in 1v1 pvp fights.A completely wrong reaction to a legitimate problem. SELF heals could have been nerfed at any time.Xelors were (are?) the time-mage class. They focus on removing your enemies ability to use as many skills on their turn. However, certain PvE bosses came out and Xelors could keep them from doing any damage.So, first they made a stacking resist occur every time Xelors were successful. ON ALL MONSTERS AND PLAYERS. (Whats the point of being punished for doing your classes job?) They later made those same PvE bosses immune to AP loss and increased both the max AP and spell cost and thus rendered the point moot, yet kept the scaling resist on everything else.But I digress...A rock-paper-scissors PvP system where there are 3-4 reigning classes at any one time, each with 0-2 classes it just cannot fight and win.A confusing swap from solo play being the focus, to full group of six players being the only way to get good experience, back to allowing solo players to fake the group dynamic with bought upgrades.--Summary--All in all I had some good times playing Wakfu with a huge guild (shoutout to Kamaradery!). The wonder of it wore off and I realized the mismanagement of the game.So, this game will entertain you and can bring you a lot of fun. Until you experience most of the content and start waiting for the developers. Then, only sadness.I truly wish the best for Wakfu in the future because it has some amazing pieces that I want to see in other games. However, I dont think I can play it any more. The people that made it great have moved on and so should I.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Cartoony, Turn-based, Free to play, but not Pay to win. Used to have a subscription system that limits free players from getting access to the goodies and content of the game, but it's all okay now. Artwork is splendid, and there is a Animated TV Series of the same name about it on Netflix. WAKFU, the game itself is very contrasting compared to other MMORPGs, mostly because of the climate, economy, and more importantly, the charater classes. It isn't just the cliche style of Warrior, Mage, and Rogue, it's more like A plentiful variety of specializations to choose from the start. For example, the Ecaflip is a class that's based on gambling, taking risks for bonuses and penalties during combat. The Sadida, is a class based on using nature to their advantage, healing allies and removing their opponents ability to traverse the terrain. On the other hand, there are a few roles that fit in the Warrior theme like the Iop. Also with the recent skill and spell revamps, the abilities of all the classes have mostly changed, including their status effects, debuffs and buffs on the skills and spells. WAKFU focuses more on a Strategic gameplay, now limiting the amount of skills you can use in combat and, putting a more emphasis on what skills you should use and exp-grind on. There's also a Economy based purely on player-trading, resource-gathering, and grinding, and a Climate system that determines effectiveness of farming of certain plants.TL:DR : Try the game, is gud stuf.

												A fun, highly addictive Final Fantasy Tactics-like game with many classes and many ways to tailor-make each calss to your style of play. Not only are there quests to complete, but there are also MANY crafting professions for you to master, from woodcutting and farming, to armour and weapon maker. The possiblities aren't endless... But there are certainly MANY of them. Start your adventure in Incarnum (the tutorial world) and learn the basics of gameplay, then choose your class and set off on your adventure!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I'll keep this review short, I have played this game for 2 years and probably have over 500+ hours in ( Yes I had no life)Pros:-Very deep game. (You can be a lumberjack, a farmer, a baker, an armorer, a leather dealer, a trapper, a governor, a guard, a miner... you get the deal)-Nice artwork, VERY colorful and relaxing. (If you love anime you'll love the art and concept of the monsters and characters)-NOT a serious game, filled with jokes and humor (To some this may be a con, but to me this was a pro)-4 Nations, and a political system. They also added a new "nation" called Riktus which are basically outlaws who do not obey laws.-plenty of classes, with each their own playstyle .Cons:-This game went free, and now you can gain an extra +20%/+30% Drop rate/exp rate (depending on the subscription you choose)  and some other little things but these DO NOT affect the game that much.- THE ONLY REAL CON HERE... is TIMEBefore you play this game, realize that this will take a chunk of your time away, to do the simplest things in this game can take an hour or two.. looking for a specific tree you want to chop down could take you from a minute to 15 minutes.And leveling also takes really long time, unless you have friends OR have multiple clients running (3 characters controlled by one person, gives me a headache)-very hard to find people for a certain dungeon, this game ENCOURAGES multiboxing (opening two clients on a single PC) which I hated very much.    That's all I have, just remember that this is a huge time waster and the only reason I quit this game is because I wanted to focus on my life a little bit more, but by all means it's a great game. Have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												I'm not devoted enough to this game to know the ins-and-outs in order to give a surefire recommendation, but boy does this game have, at the very least, potential, and even decent delivery.For one thing, there's a truckload of playable character classes with their own abilities, all of which not just have their own compelling gameplay identities, but three different proposed styles within them that allow you to 'build' one the way you want. And all of those abilities take, like, no time at all unlock. Streamlines the process in a way I don't mind, as from then on really all it's building up to is making those abilities more powerful, and even that's made as easy as possible without taking the grinding out of it. Various effects and damages scale with bonus damage provided by items, and every now and then if you're no happy with the level of your abilities, or the way you've allocated your stats, you can just re-do it (albeit only once a month for whatever wierd reason).And then I guess second is the turn-based grid-based pseudo-strategy approach to combat. Fresh breath of air, and it works well, though this is one of those wierd MMOs where you have to do not-combat things, but they still use the combat system for whatever reason and it looks incredibly out of place and is unnecessarily complicated. Only those things though, actual battles are just fine.The english localization is kind of a bang-up job, as all these types of games tend to be. And certain systems being as complicated as they are means this doesn't help learning the game very much. It took me about halfway in to my current playtime to realize what Lock and Dodge even did, so either I can blame that on the game or tell you to do what I didn't and go do some research.There's also buddings of a Runescape-lite kind of thing going on where you have different crafting and harvesting skills and using them levels them up. This is not a bad thing, I like Runescape, and it's nice to make it feel like you don't need to invest in combat to see most of what the game has to offer, but going the whole hog and having freaking full-on ecosystem management puts player-to-player trust at arms. Everyone can plant the seeds of the things they just cut down to resupply for anyone else who wants to cut them, but there's nothing going on to say you must.EDIT: Playing it again after putting it down I did remember one other problem with it. Most of the game's dungeons say they're supposed to be done at certain levels, but you can only do them that way if you have a party of friends with you. It makes no concessions for solo players, and it's not exactly the best environment for finding people to help you out.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												In the massively multiplayer online game WAKFU, players have to use the skills and smarts to survive, battle and build in a virgin universe. Characters fight fierce fauna and flora using magic, martial arts or new technologies. They also have to build cities in a virgin universe while preserving nature from destruction. Thanks to a universal and intuitive language, players will interact to create alliances or to take part in fights that will have a direct influence upon the universe.The story of Wakfu takes place a long time after that of DOFUS. An ogre named Ogrest gathered all the six Dofus and gained boundless powers. The ogre offered his beloved the dragon eggs. But she turned down the present though worthy of the gods themselves, and Ogrest started shedding tears of rage and pique. The tears of the ogre made the ocean level increase so much that parts of the World are now submerged to the inhabitants' great displeasure. Now gods and heroes of the World are starting a new adventure before reaching Ogrest and confront him in an ultimate fight!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												It tries its best to make its way out of the shadow of Dofus (Ankama's First TBSMMO) but fails. The classes are better and the combat feels deeper but the grind is even worse. Most of my time playing It felt like almost every feature they tried to improved from Dofus was more of a step back. The F2p model is a joke its one of those Booster subscription deals and some of the stuff in the cash shop does not really make sense. While the nations were a interesting idea there is balance problem and over time it has made Ankama set most of each nations maps to be almost the same so as not to smooth the leveling curve. Gods help you though if you need to get to another nation that your at war with, The political system is heavily abuse-able. I'm not sure if its a problem in this version but it was a huge problem in the beta. Multi boxing is still alive and well so that mmo part is not really there though other players that are willing to help are a dime a dozen.In the end it would have just been better if they merged the Stats, Spells and Combat system into Dofus and called it day. Maybe the haven bag too, that idea wasn't too bad.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I want to like Wakfu I really do, but it has to many glaring flaws for me to recomend it.Lets start with the pros.+ great art+ Interesting classes+ fun combat system+ Interesting lore (including the anime)Now... to the cons- no quests: Wakfu lacks quests and expects you to just be happy raiding dungeons on your own without anyone telling you to. This is doesnt work as you will soon fin yourself tried to doing nothing but running into the same dungeons over and over. Which might have been ok if...- dungeons suck: sad but true. The dungeons are ok on your first play through, but without a party there is no real strategy to beating them, either your strong enough or your not. And even when your playing with friends to make the experience more engaging, once you beat a dungeon your basicaly done. Sure you might grind it for drops but ther fun has since gone. The dungeons never change so once you have beat it once, unless you AFK, you will always beat it from that point out.  This could have worked if there were a ton of dungeons, but there are not there are maybe 5 per area and you wll stay in each area for about 10 or so levels which can take mutliple dungeon runs to acomplish. And yet even this might have been ok, if getting epic loot was fun, but...-the loot sucks: the loot variety is small, like really small, and without random stats attached to any of it there is no reason to get it. You will raid a dungeon once, get the loot then never return, or better yet just buy it off somone for cheap because since everyone has the exact same loot its all worthless! Which could be ok if leveling your character was fun, but...-progression sucks: Its basic gaming design to make sure the player isnt doing the same thing at level 100 as they were at level 1. That will not happen here, sure you will find leveling up to about 25 or so, engaging, but from then on out your character will not change at all. You will be using the same combos over and over and over again with no real motivation to change it up, the only thing that will change is how much damage they do. But luckily there is somethign other than fighting, there is crafting so that....- crafting also sucks: The game doesnt enforce you to have one job, you can do any, because of this your job is worthless. Everyone just makes anything they need themselves and ebcause of this everything on the market is either dirt cheep or super expensive. The idea of running a armor making store sounds fun, untill you realize no one will ever buy from you when they can just make it themselves and earn exp while doing it. This has an easy fix (force people to have only a single job) Which the games text says is how the system works! But it doesn't and they havent fixed it, so it fails.So in short Wakfu is a game where your character doesnt grow past level 25, in which you grind repetative dungeons for borring loot. To the tune of no story and no meaningfull jobs or minigame to complete. Sounds fun no?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												In the past, Wakfu was a terrible F2P MMO. All the business model cared for was money money money. Players weren't able to get in-game currency and you weren't able to leave the newbie area unless you were a subscriber to the game.Now everything has changed. F2P players can go to the zones that subscribers were able to go to, and monsters drop in-game currency (in the past, the only way you were able to get money as a subscriber was by minting it.)The only downside to this is that the in-game currency minting machines are almost obsolete now unless they revamp that system somehow to make money-minting more profitable than grinding. But in the past items were much more cheaper than they were due to the fact that money HAD to be minted to order to get money. Now everything is a lot more expensive.Overall if you like games that play like FF Tactics or FF Tactics Advance for fighting, as well as games that have job professions, and a Havest Moon like open world where you are able to plant things that grow (even monsters,) try this game out.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Had to Edit this review due to massive changes in the game since it was written. Prior to this, it was 57 of 67 Helpful, and I recommended it.However, due to these changes, I can no longer recommend this trainwreck of a game.It seemed like they made such good decisions with the initial steam release. Class fixes/overhauls to make them useful and fun again, removal of most of the "pay to even play let alone win" mechanics.But then they redid a number of classes, again. Including my beloved Zookeeper Osa. What once was the only class I genuinely enjoyed, with a stable full of pets I could summon 3 or 4 pets at once with, has been transformed into a shadow of it's former self with only a single pet allowed, some stupid new buff/energy system, and all my previous skills (and thus my gear) being rendered mostly useless.This is on top of the LOOOOOOOOONG-awaited "Hero" system turning out to be complete Everyone was expecting this new system that let you use Alt chars on the same account as Sidekicks/Party Members, since previously, everyone had multiple accounts anyways with alts in their party - so we figured, "Cool, they're going to implement a system to make this official and easier on both us and the servers."WRONG. The Hero system is a monthly subscription, which costs more per-char you want to add, and highly overpriced. People were waiting for this to come out and be the game-saver, what made the community skyrocket, instead, people quit in droves, major cities that once had dozens or hundreds of shop bags out are now empty, and the pop has dropped outside of the French servers.They also took the main neutral gathering point, the Temple in Astrub, and literally deleted the entire area where everyone had their shop bags and socialized and had duels at, so there's no room to do anything social there anymore. The developers. actively. removed. socialization. On purpose.What was once a good, fun little game has been destroyed by terrible decisions. RIP Wakfu.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Be careful. Once you join the world of Wakfu you will find yourself very addicted and you will only be talking to your in-game friends. For those who have lives....BEWARE!But, seriously this game is good! c:EDIT: They changed the entire battle system which is what made this game fun. The system is now just an annoying hassle and the support team for this game barely try to assist you if anything happens. The game is buggy and constantly changing for better and worse. I regret spending so much time on this game only for them to ruin it for me.The ECOSYSTEM in this game. What do I mean? Wakfu is unique in the sense that the players control the ecosystem of the world which also applies to the shops. If someone chops down all the trees they will be gone from an area forever until someone plants them back. This causes a lot of annoying problems especially because a lot of people just go to an area to "ecoterrorize" it because they are from the enemy nation. Having to plant things back takes a very long time and it is very boring. Things HAVE become close to impossible to find in this game. One of those things are beans...yes, beans. In the NA server Nox you can't find them anywhere and it is only a matter of time before more in-game resources become extinct and you won't be able to craft important items.That player influence also pollutes the in-game MARKET. In Wakfu there are no npcs that sell you items, everything is sold by other players. You can imagine how this influences the prices of things you need in the game especially if you are new.From levels 120-145 (I believe) there is nothing to do but grind. Grind the same 3 or so dungeons over and over until you make it to 145. I've spent hours grinding and by the time I quit the game my character was level 134. It just didn't feel worth it to me. Beyond level grinding is the relic grinding. You need to do the same 2-3 hour dungeon to MAYBE get a relic about every 5 runs just to get a good item. It's ridiculous especially in my personal experience where the game glitched and all my relics disappeared (I had like 30) and when I sent in a support ticket they just gave me a rare costume and an emote as conpensation...but all my time grinding was for nothing.CONCLUSION:This game feels really good in the beginning but late-game it just seriously becomes a head ache especially when you notice all your in-game friends have quit. All the new updates just make the game feel even worse because Ankama only adds things and never fixes what already exists in the game. You're honestly better off watching the series on Netflix but even that is decent at best.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Wakfu has a look and style I find enjoyable. One drawback on this it sometimes hinders gameplay (especially on the battlefield!!!) as you cannot turn the camera. The action resolves around turn based battles on various grids with variation in size, pattern, elevations and some in accessible locations. These battles are fun, Tactics and knowledge of your character, ofcourse when grouping up - the team play, brings you a lot to amuse yourself with. There seems to be a intricate crating system in place. The flaw is that there is too little information in the game itself on many gameplay facets beside the tutorial wich learns you to navigate your character and his abilities. No explanation or not enough explanation can be found on topics like the environment, crafting, guilds, havens, special tokens, especially nations!!! what they do how the function in respect to others, and the UI is not optimal. Spoken to a lot of players who already spent some time in the game being ignorant about tabs on windows in the game giving them access to a lot more character options, just to name a simple example. It has a lot of potential for a great game and hours of gametime.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Wakfu is one of my all-time favourite games.As far as MMO elements go, It's fun to play cooperatively, but it's perfectly possible to go it alone, with sufficient grinding, of course.For the RPG aspects, Wakfu offers a great (and I do mean great) variety of classes and customisation options within each class, so that everybody can tailor their respective incarnations to their playstyles, and have no two be quite exactly the same.The turn-based, boardgame-like combat is a fast, fun, and all-around enjoyable experience that never gets old, thanks to the wide variety of playstyles, monsters, and environmental properties.And not to forget the art and music: The music is a combination of relaxed environmental tracks and epic orchestral battle themes (Inspirational to say the very least); and the art-style, as inspired by the artist Xa-Xa-Xa on Deviantart is as absolutely, stunningly lovely as ever, with vibrant and imaginative worlds and creatures within those worlds, and the character models are just the right balance of adorable and badass.Wakfu is a wonderful game that I would recommend to just about anybody. And it's free, too!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												WAKFU is a highly complex, immersive 'world' with its own laws, politics, international-relations, ecology, and economy.   Learning how all of those forces interact is the great challenge of WAKFU, this is not a simple 'shooter', but a community with a range of player personalities ranging from open, helpful and friendly ... to darkest, evil villains.     Players choose for themselves what role they will play, and quickly learn their actions have consequences, especially when ones actions are contrary to the wishes of the local 'clan members'.   There are many paths to success in WAKFU, players may choose from a wide range of character classes, and professions.WAKFU has its problems too, particularly the publisher: Ankama, seems to have a great many problems with real world payment processing for many players attempting to purchase items from their 'shop' for use in the game.   Fixing these issues does not seem to be a priority for Ankama whose customer support seems quite lacking.If one is willing to accept the lack of support from the publisher, the game itself is still worth a look, as to a large degree, WAKFU's world is what, we, the players, make it.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I would recommend this to anyone who has a strategic mind and loves to plan their move, each turn the player has time to plan their move (Around 30 seconds I believe) within those thirty seconds you can plan your attack your move, and attempt to coordinate your attacks with a team mate, playing this with my friend was very interesting. We had to coordinate our attacks so he wouldn't hit me, as he was playing a character with AOE attacks.  I recommend this game simply because it's an interesting take on MMORPGs instead of being a stand and attack like so many others, (Which I will not name) this relies on a grid system of which you can maximize your advantage through strategic planning. Overall, I give it a 9.5/10 for its interesting gameplay.

												..it's a fun game.. if you like to play farm.v, you can farm here.if you like playing city.v, you can build your city inside a Haven World or decorate your haven bag.if you like adventure, there are quests and story-line for you.if you like to just socialize and get new friends, u can chat and do interactive action with the avatar.if you enjoy pvp, there are pvp sites especially for pvp fans.if you love to run dungeons, wakfu has a lot of dungeons to run. the only thing you need is to find a group. or run the dungeons solo with the accompany of sidekicks.if you like to feel accomplishing something, wakfu has a long list of achivement you can try to complete.There are a lot of stuff to do in wakfu, as it is a player driven economy.Join an active guild. aside from getting bonuses and better chance to get parties, Guilds also organize Events for their members. Dont worry we are international players with English speaking community. and the community consist of all players around the globe.Phaeris server is the friendliest community in Wakfu and we welcome newbies.Market price for most items in Phaeris is a lot cheaper too. content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												First of all most games that you can play these days are easy mode meaning it doesn't take much to get to the end game.  Most F2P games ask you to spend everything you have to get ahead, including the shirt on your back. This game isn't either. It takes a lot of effort to level up and everyone is equal (not P2W). Ya sure there are perks to this game when you buy booster packs but it's not a lot in the way that it would put you at a higher class than others so you can be OP. It's well balanced with good graphics and music. It even has some humor in it to make you laugh. So if you want a game to take your mind off things (spend hours out of reality and beat things up to exact your fustration), need a good laugh, see graphics that are pleasing to the eye, and maybe even feel like dancing to good tunes then this game is for YOU! It's a well balanced turn based game so some may not like it but for those who like or even love turn based games then give this a try. What will it hurt?? :-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												I'm not devoted enough to this game to know the ins-and-outs in order to give a surefire recommendation, but boy does this game have, at the very least, potential, and even decent delivery.For one thing, there's a truckload of playable character classes with their own abilities, all of which not just have their own compelling gameplay identities, but three different proposed styles within them that allow you to 'build' one the way you want. And all of those abilities take, like, no time at all unlock. Streamlines the process in a way I don't mind, as from then on really all it's building up to is making those abilities more powerful, and even that's made as easy as possible without taking the grinding out of it. Various effects and damages scale with bonus damage provided by items, and every now and then if you're no happy with the level of your abilities, or the way you've allocated your stats, you can just re-do it (albeit only once a month for whatever wierd reason).And then I guess second is the turn-based grid-based pseudo-strategy approach to combat. Fresh breath of air, and it works well, though this is one of those wierd MMOs where you have to do not-combat things, but they still use the combat system for whatever reason and it looks incredibly out of place and is unnecessarily complicated. Only those things though, actual battles are just fine.The english localization is kind of a bang-up job, as all these types of games tend to be. And certain systems being as complicated as they are means this doesn't help learning the game very much. It took me about halfway in to my current playtime to realize what Lock and Dodge even did, so either I can blame that on the game or tell you to do what I didn't and go do some research.There's also buddings of a Runescape-lite kind of thing going on where you have different crafting and harvesting skills and using them levels them up. This is not a bad thing, I like Runescape, and it's nice to make it feel like you don't need to invest in combat to see most of what the game has to offer, but going the whole hog and having freaking full-on ecosystem management puts player-to-player trust at arms. Everyone can plant the seeds of the things they just cut down to resupply for anyone else who wants to cut them, but there's nothing going on to say you must.EDIT: Playing it again after putting it down I did remember one other problem with it. Most of the game's dungeons say they're supposed to be done at certain levels, but you can only do them that way if you have a party of friends with you. It makes no concessions for solo players, and it's not exactly the best environment for finding people to help you out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												In the massively multiplayer online game WAKFU, players have to use the skills and smarts to survive, battle and build in a virgin universe. Characters fight fierce fauna and flora using magic, martial arts or new technologies. They also have to build cities in a virgin universe while preserving nature from destruction. Thanks to a universal and intuitive language, players will interact to create alliances or to take part in fights that will have a direct influence upon the universe.The story of Wakfu takes place a long time after that of DOFUS. An ogre named Ogrest gathered all the six Dofus and gained boundless powers. The ogre offered his beloved the dragon eggs. But she turned down the present though worthy of the gods themselves, and Ogrest started shedding tears of rage and pique. The tears of the ogre made the ocean level increase so much that parts of the World are now submerged to the inhabitants' great displeasure. Now gods and heroes of the World are starting a new adventure before reaching Ogrest and confront him in an ultimate fight!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												--Edit--As of the update to 1.43 myself as well as several other people I've talked to in-game have not been able to purchase the in-game currency for their shop (Ogrines). I attempted to report the issue to Ankama support but they were rude and dismissive, sending me to Steam support saying my account was being restricted per the "Trading and Market Restrictions" (found at https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=1047-EDFM-2932 ).I forwarded them a screenshot of my purchase history and explained how this policy did not affect me based on my purchase history. They responded with this:-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Please accept our sincerest apologies.However, we have already endorsed this case to a higher level of customer support. Unfortunately, they have made their decision and have stated it as final. Therefore, we are unable to reverse it or force a different outcome. We understand that decision is not according to your expectations.As per our previous message, we are unfortunately not able to provide you more assistance on this issue.For a breakdown of the new purchase restrictions enforced by Steam, they are as follows:+Steam accounts are not allowed any purchase unless they had a successful purchase older than 30 days but not older than 1 year.+The successful purchase (meaning the transaction was not cancelled or refunded) of wallet funds, games, DLCs and software meet this requirement.+Retail CD key activations and gift purchases do not meet this requirement and will not lift the purchase restrictions on a Steam account.Please opt to contact the Steam Customer Support for further assistance. Apologies for the inconvenience.Kind regards,------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I will update this review whenever I get the problem solved, but as for now I am at my wits end. I cannot recommend the game until they show better commitment to solving (at least) paying customer's issues in a timely manner.--Edit End--I love this game. It's artwork is amazing, It has an almost entirely player driven world from the ecosystem to nations ruled by PCs. Wars are fought as much through ecoterrorism as face to face combat. There are a multitude of guilds which fill in gameplay between storyline quests (if the national dramas aren't enough!) The system can be a bit buggy as stated in previous reviews but no-where near the point where the game loses playability. It is turn-based but there is also a turn timer which keeps things moving fairly well. The classes don't quite use traditional roles (tank, dps, healer, ect.) per say. In many cases you CAN build your character to strictly fill one of these roles and you'll find tons of guides on the Ankama forums to help you do so. That being said, MOST classes you can build to fill one or two roles successfully or a well rounded solo character that has just as good playability and balance in a group filling a role.The game is great, it gets monthly updates, it blends with an anime that even further immerses you into the World of Twelve. And it's highly addictive. 10/10 all around. Give it a shot and you'll be hooked!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9
												I downloaded this today and really enjoyed it.  Very unique to see a turn based MMO and I absolutely loved the combat.  Lots of different types of enemies and interesting set of skills to use.  Im not far into the game but I found the story to be interesting, the gameplay very enjoyable and there were quite a few people playing online and of the few that I talked to they all said they love the game.  Also worth noting that I had no issues at all with performance as has been put forward by other people.  My laptop is average at best as well and no issues at all.  Not saying others are lying but just my experience was fine.  The game did take a good 10 minutes to start though on 1st launch due to updates. The game world is absolutely huge.  Loads of different islands/counties, gorgeous artwork, engaging combat system and so much replayability with 13 different classes.Now for what I wasnt so keen on.  The timer on the combat system.  I actually think its a great idea, expecially for PVP so people dont take forever but I think when you are learning the game it should be disabled.  You only get 30 seconds to make your moves and when you dont know the game or what different buffs and debuffs are in play I found myself paniking at times which doesnt suit the relaxing nature of the game.  Like I say great idea but I think it should only apply for level 10.  I then started to get confused by the crafting.  To the point that I turned it off.  So many professions and things to craft that I found it daunting.  Im not going to give up though.  The game has interested me enough to do some reading up on the subject on the forums.I think this game has potential to take over my life if I allow it. If turn based games in a fantasy MMO setting interests you then i strongly advise you to give this a go.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												If you're a jaded MMO player then seriously check this game out. It's just completely different from what you've probably played before which I found refreshing. Pros: Its off the wall humour: from the armorsets you can acquire to the descriptions of items, you'll find yourself reading everything as the game really doesn't take itself too seriously. It's also incredibly cute in places, but you really don't have to enjoy anime to appreciate it.Complex character building and tactical gameplay - It does take awhile to get use to and requires a fair amount of reading wiki/forum posts to understand how best to level your character, but once you've got your head around the main points, it's just so much fun developing the skillsets you want to play with. Environments - The game enables the players to control resources (including mob spawning) through environmental management. It's a fun twist on the normal mmo conventions and enables you to take aside an area of land and start your own small holding should you wish or spawn mobs if you're just out to hunt. Its a good way to get resources, which you can use or sell to tradeskillers, but it's also just a fun way to spend time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												The gameplay at its core is solid.  It's definitely an MMORPG.  There's lots of options in terms of attire, fighting style, spells, weaponry, enchantments, and other things.  Playing free has yet to reveal any immediate disadvantages against paying players beyond the obvious slightly slower leveling.  The developers update well and update often, as far as I can see.However.I've only just started this game and let me say before I'm any more experienced:  This game is confusing as hell.  You aren't told much of what you're getting into, what to do, or how to do it beyond combat and interacting with things/people.The overcrowding of the screen and most hub locations doesn't help either.  The chat window is often obtrusive, the hint windows are only circumstantially helpful and are not worth the entire corner of the screen they take up, and the quest system is either buggy or has yet to reveal its mysteries to me.  Often in combat you will look at the statuses you're inflicted with and ask yourself: "what is that?  What is it doing?  Why do I have it?"  When it comes time to join a nation, you are given almost no informaton about any of them beyond their total wealth, who they're allied with/enemies with, and the amount of the playerbase they hold.And that's what makes it absolutely beautiful.  This is the most granular, inaccessible, 80%-complete-at-all-times game I have ever played, and I personally believe that's what makes it an MMO.  Play this game.  Do it.  It will be confusing but it's the best kind of confused I've ever been.  You learn as you go, and the confusion wears off, and feeling it wear off is the best kind of feeling I've gotten out of games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I'm honestly torn how to rate this game. Love the community, hate the developers. Beautiful art too!My opinions are based off of roughly May, 2015. Some of this may have changed. Most probably hasn't.--History, Positives about the game--I played the title since beta v0.2 and loved the class system, was intrigued by the "no NPCs" rule (except territory masters), LOVED that original crafting system, and LOVED the open (grid based) world where you could plant resources anywhere you wanted or cut everything down! >:D However, everything was in French. I learned a lot of French.Then they remade it (beta v0.3) with English support. I kept playing but the crafting system was replaced with a typical gather-craft grind. Still great open-world sandbox game. They added more classes so combat was more interesting, guilds developed. The community was super great, with a handful of ... inciting personalities.Time is getting muddled in my brain, but somewhere in there we reached full 12 (then 13, then 14...) classes, Wakfu "left beta", it was released on Steam, EA signed on to manage the North American server, quests developed, guilds developed even further, and much more area, mechanics, and equipment were added into the game. Good things.--Drawbacks--However, I have never been part of a game where the developers were more sluggish in responding to the people.Patches come once a month at best. Sometimes three months pass without a change. Then BOOM everything is changed, a few barely noticable hotfixes in the days that follow, then, silence.They have a terrible tendency to balance a class around PvP OR PvE. Never both. (Also, huge favortism with developers and certain classes they work on. Trying to outdo one another?)Classes have gone unbalanced for AGES and developers would rather wait years to remake the class entirely rather than tune some numbers. Sometimes these class changes completely gut the core identity of a class.Example time!Eniripsas (healers, my preferred main) went TWO YEARS with both a mechanic that made healing more effective (by flat bonus per spell) and less effective (by scaled percentage) in long fights. Two mechanics that fought each other.They didn't tune numbers. They didn't get rid of the passive that was the issue. They took the power of the class (extending fights) and made it impossible to do so because a good healer couldn't die in 1v1 pvp fights.A completely wrong reaction to a legitimate problem. SELF heals could have been nerfed at any time.Xelors were (are?) the time-mage class. They focus on removing your enemies ability to use as many skills on their turn. However, certain PvE bosses came out and Xelors could keep them from doing any damage.So, first they made a stacking resist occur every time Xelors were successful. ON ALL MONSTERS AND PLAYERS. (Whats the point of being punished for doing your classes job?) They later made those same PvE bosses immune to AP loss and increased both the max AP and spell cost and thus rendered the point moot, yet kept the scaling resist on everything else.But I digress...A rock-paper-scissors PvP system where there are 3-4 reigning classes at any one time, each with 0-2 classes it just cannot fight and win.A confusing swap from solo play being the focus, to full group of six players being the only way to get good experience, back to allowing solo players to fake the group dynamic with bought upgrades.--Summary--All in all I had some good times playing Wakfu with a huge guild (shoutout to Kamaradery!). The wonder of it wore off and I realized the mismanagement of the game.So, this game will entertain you and can bring you a lot of fun. Until you experience most of the content and start waiting for the developers. Then, only sadness.I truly wish the best for Wakfu in the future because it has some amazing pieces that I want to see in other games. However, I dont think I can play it any more. The people that made it great have moved on and so should I.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I've played Dofus years ago and enjoyed every minute of it. I can say the same about Wakfu. There's a lot of freedom, fun and enjoyable content in this game. Turn based combat forces you to think alot about your moves and lets you plan your movement in the future turns. The world is huge and well done. Another feature that should be noticed is that there's no NPC shops. There's an auction house, where people create economy and dictate prices. I also enjoy profession and crafting system. I find leveling up my crafting/harvesting skills very enjoyable. All in all, I could talk a lot about this game, but you should try it for yourselves. After all, it's free to play.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												This is a good game.Where to start. First of all,wakfu is a multi media idea. There are shows,comics,and the game. Of course,this is gonna be about the game.The creators appear to have worked their best to keep the game from a p2w platform,as all the thingd you can buy in the shop are either cosmetic or has severe downsides to it,such as the garden haven gem. Gardening in the world gives you experience toward Farming or Lumberjack,depending on if you're tending to trees or crops,but planting things in your haven bag grants no xp to the skills. All of the armor in the shop is also cosmetic,and everything has to be earned,whether you like it or not. The closest thing to a p2w is subscriber status,which grants you bonus items after a fight and more XP after a fight,along with a potion that makes crafting easier. In short,wakfu is a game where you CAN buy things with real money,but they are only minor things that make things more convenient while also introducing a downside to those conveniences. A good amount of store items can also be earned,such as a garden haven gem being able to be gotten by praying at the Almanax Altar for 60 days in a row,or completing certain dungeins.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												Wakfu is not a game; its a lifestyle.  where your actions effect the whole of a mmo world. there is many things you can do, from crafting or performing a profession such as armorer, or farming. or defeating dungeons useing a tactical rpg format. after 2 overhauls of the way skills work and how stats are effected, the game is more balanced.  in addition to skills making more sence, and easy to upgrade them from lvling. i like the feature of the haven bag/world. haveing your own extra storage that you can carry along with you; customize with bedroom sets, garden gems(for growing stuff), and crafting tables-so you can do professions or craft on the go/collect and save plants for later use. what i dont like is that the official site gives more buyable options-even though donation rewards overall dont overpower your progression over others in any big or lasting way. i would like the option to change my name or get any of the other things steam wakfu shop doesnt have that official site shop does.       but after going over merit and flaw balance, then compared to other games of style type or what is available during this era of gaming, i give it a 8/10.  and definately recommend other to pick it up and play it.
